{{Use Hong Kong English|date=February 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2011}} {{Infobox bridge | name = Hong Kong–Zhuhai–Macau Bridge | native_name = {{nobold|{{lang|zh-hant|港珠澳大橋}}
{{lang|zh-hans|港珠澳大桥}}
{{lang|pt|Ponte Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau}}}} | image = File:West section of Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge (20180902174105).jpg | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | coordinates = | os_grid_reference = | carries = 6 lanes of the [[File:China Expwy G94 sign with name.png|20px]] [[G94 Pearl River Delta Ring Expressway]] | crosses = * [[Pearl River Delta|Pearl River Estuary]] ** [[Lingdingyang|Lingding Channel]] ** [[Jiuzhouyang|Jiuzhou Channel]] | locale = [[Pearl River Delta]] | official_name = Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge | other_name = HZMB | named_for = | owner = | maint = | heritage = | id = | id_type = | website = {{URL|hzmb.org}} (Mainland site)
{{URL|hzmb.hk}} (Hong Kong site)
{{URL|http://www.dsat.gov.mo/hzmb/}} (Macau site) | preceded = | followed = | design = [[Bridge–tunnel]] system | material = | material1 = | material2 = | length = {{convert|55|km|mi}} | width = | height = | depth = | traversable = | towpath = | mainspan = | number_spans =3 | piers_in_water = | load = | clearance_above = | clearance_below = | lanes = 6 | life =120 years | architect = | designer = | contracted_designer = | winner = | engineering = | builder = | fabricator = | begin = 15 December 2009 | complete = 6 February 2018{{cite web |url=http://www.gov.cn/xinwen/2018-02/06/content_5264425.htm |script-title=zh:港珠澳大桥主体工程完成交工验收 具备通车试运营条件 |website=Central People's Government of the People's Republic of China |date=2018-02-06 |accessdate=2018-10-24 }} | cost = [[Renminbi|¥]] 126.9 billion ([[USD|$]] {{To USD|126.9|China}} billion){{cite web |url=http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-10/23/c_137553194.htm|title=Xinhua Headlines: World's longest cross-sea bridge opens, integrating China's Greater Bay Area|website=Xinhua Net|date=2018-10-23 |accessdate=2018-10-24 }} | open = 24 October 2018, 9 A.M. UTC+8 {{cite web |url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/2169893/first-cars-and-buses-begin-crossing-pearl-river-delta-hong |title=Cars and buses begin crossing the Pearl River Delta as Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge opens to traffic|accessdate=2018-10-24 |date=2018-10-24}}{{cite web | url=https://www.scmp.com/video/china/2169817/chinese-president-xi-jinping-declares-hong-kong-zhuhai-macau-bridge-open | title=Xi Jinping declares opening of Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge}} | inaugurated =23 October 2018 by [[Xi Jinping]], President of China | rebuilt = | collapsed = | closed = | replaces = | replaced_by = | traffic = | toll = | map_type = | map_relief = | map_dot_label = | map_image = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | extra = }} {{Chinese | s = 港珠澳大桥 | t = 港珠澳大橋 | showflag = jp | p = Gǎngzhū'ào Dàqiáo | y = Góngjyūou Daaihkìuh | j = gong2 zyu1 ou3 daai6 kiu4 | lang1 = Portuguese | lang1_content = Ponte Hong Kong–Zhuhai–Macau | pic = HZMB route.svg | piccap = Map of the bridge highway and the undersea tunnel (dotted) route of the Hong Kong–Zhuhai–Macau Bridge, between [[Hong Kong]] and [[Macau]]. }} The '''Hong Kong–Zhuhai–Macau Bridge''' ('''HZMB'''), officially the '''Hong Kong–Zhuhai–Macao Bridge''', is a {{convert|55|km|mi|adj=on}} [[bridge–tunnel]] system consisting of a series of three [[cable-stayed bridge]]s, an [[undersea tunnel]], and four [[artificial islands]]. It is both the longest sea crossing{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-45937924|title=China opens longest sea-crossing bridge|date=2018-10-23|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-GB}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/smooth-start-for-worlds-longest-sea-crossing|title=Smooth start for world's longest state of the art sea crossing|last=hermes|date=2018-10-25|work=The Straits Times|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en}} and the longest [[Intercontinental and transoceanic fixed links|fixed link]] on earth. The HZMB spans the [[Lingdingyang|Lingding]] and [[Jiuzhouyang|Jiuzhou]] channels, connecting [[Hong Kong]], [[Macau]], and [[Zhuhai]]—three major cities on the [[Pearl River Delta]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.caixinglobal.com/2017-12-08/whats-the-cost-of-a-ride-on-the-worlds-longest-bridge-over-water-101182465.html|title=What's the Cost of a Ride on the World's Longest Bridge Over Water? - Caixin Global|website=www.caixinglobal.com|language=en|access-date=2018-10-24}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.rt.com/news/434881-longest-bridge-photos-world/|title=Satellite shots show epic scale of world's longest oversea bridge (IMAGES)|work=RT International|access-date=2018-10-24|language=en-US}} The HZMB was designed to last for 120 years and built with a cost of 126.9 billion [[Yuan (currency)|yuan]] (US$ {{To USD|126.9|China}} billion).{{Cite web|url=http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-10/23/c_137553194.htm|title=Xinhua Headlines: World's longest cross-sea bridge opens, integrating China's Greater Bay Area - Xinhua {{!}} English.news.cn|website=www.xinhuanet.com|access-date=2018-10-27}} The cost of constructing the Main Bridge was estimated at 51.1 billion yuan (US$ 7.56 billion) funded by bank loans and shared among the governments of mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau.{{Cite news|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/05/04/asia/hong-kong-zhuhai-macau-bridge/index.html|title=China unveils world's longest sea-crossing bridge|last=CNN|first=Sarah Lazarus,|work=CNN|access-date=2018-10-28}} Originally set to be opened to traffic in late 2016,{{Cite web|url=https://asia.nikkei.com/Politics-Economy/Economy/Hong-Kong-Zhuhai-Macau-Bridge-construction-set-to-finish-this-year|title=Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge construction set to finish this year|website=Nikkei Asian Review|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-10-28}}{{cite web |last1=The Standard |title=Bridge to open in one go despite HK delays |url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/section-news.php?id=173208 |accessdate=22 October 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161022223108/http://www.thestandard.com.hk/section-news.php?id=173208 |archivedate=22 October 2016 |df=dmy-all}} the structure was completed on 6 February 2018{{Cite web|url=http://www.gov.cn/xinwen/2018-02/06/content_5264425.htm |script-title=zh:港珠澳大桥主体工程完成交工验收具备通车试运营条件_滚动新闻_中国政府网|last=刘淼|website=www.gov.cn|access-date=2018-10-27}} and journalists were subsequently given rides over the bridge.{{Cite news |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/05/04/asia/hong-kong-zhuhai-macau-bridge/index.html |title=China unveils world's longest sea-crossing bridge |last=CNN |first=Sarah Lazarus, |work=CNN |access-date=2018-08-16}}{{Cite web |url=http://gd.qq.com/a/20180121/010630.htm |script-title=zh:好消息！港珠澳大桥七一前正式通车_大粤网_腾讯网 |website=gd.qq.com |language=zh-CN |access-date=2018-02-08 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180209002714/http://gd.qq.com/a/20180121/010630.htm |archivedate=9 February 2018 |df=dmy-all}} On 24 October 2018, the HZMB was opened to the public after its inauguration a day earlier by [[Xi Jinping]], [[General Secretary of the Communist Party of China]] and [[President of the People's Republic of China]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-10/23/c_137552885_3.htm|title=Xi announces opening of Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge|website=Xinhua|language=en|access-date=2018-10-23}} == Planning == === Background === [[Hopewell Holdings]] founder and then-managing director [[Gordon Wu]] proposed the concept of a bridge-tunnel linking China, Hong Kong and Macau in the 1980s.{{Cite news|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/hong-kong-economy/article/2169864/property-tycoon-gordon-wus-35-year-dream-massive|title=Tycoon’s 35-year dream finally realised as mega bridge opens|last=Tsang|first=Denise|date=2018-10-23|work=South China Morning Post|access-date=2018-10-23}} Wu stated that he got the idea in 1983 from the [[Chesapeake Bay Bridge–Tunnel]]. In 1988, Wu pitched the concept to Guangdong and Beijing officials. He envisaged a link farther north than the current design, beginning at Black Point near [[Tuen Mun]], Hong Kong and crossing the Pearl River estuary via [[Nei Lingding Island|Neilingding Island]] and [[Qi'ao Island]]. His proposed bridge would end at the Chinese village of Tangjia, and a new road would continue south through Zhuhai before terminating at Macau.{{cite news |last1=Stoner |first1=Tad |title=$6b bridge to China plan |work=South China Morning Post |date=3 November 1988 |page=1}} Discussions stalled after the [[Tiananmen Square protests of 1989|Tiananmen Square massacre]] in mid-1989 "unnerved" Wu and other foreign investors, and caused Hopewell's Hong Kong share prices to plunge.{{cite news |last1=Hunt |first1=Christopher |title=Entrepreneur Becomes a Weather Vane For Resuming Business in China Now |work=The Wall Street Journal, Eastern edition |date=29 December 1989 |page=1}} The route proposed by Wu was promoted by the government of [[Zhuhai]] under the name [[Lingdingyang Bridge]]. In the mid-1990s, Zhuhai built a bridge between the mainland and Qi'ao Island that was intended as the first phase of this route, though the full scheme had not been approved by either the Chinese nor Hong Kong governments at that time.{{cite news |last1=Cheung |first1=Agnes |title=First Lingdingyang link nearly ready |work=South China Morning Post |date=29 March 1995 |page=11}} China's central government showed support for this project on 30 December 1997.{{cite news |last1=Szeto |first1=Wanda |last2=Ng |first2=Kang-chung |title=Beijing approves Zhuhai-HK bridge |work=South China Morning Post |page=1 |date=31 December 1997}} The new Hong Kong government was reticent, stating that it was still awaiting cross-border traffic study results, and Hong Kong media questioned the environmental impact of the project with regard to air pollution, traffic and marine life.{{cite news |title=A bridge too far |work=South China Morning Post |date=2 January 1998 |page=12}} In December 2001, the [[Legislative Council of Hong Kong]] passed a motion urging the Administration to develop the logistics industry including the construction of a bridge connecting Hong Kong, Zhuhai and Macao. At a meeting of the China/Hong Kong Conference on Co-ordination of Major Infrastructure Projects held on 20 September 2002, it was agreed that a joint study should be conducted on the transport link between Hong Kong and Pearl River West.{{Cite web|url=https://www.legco.gov.hk/database/english/data_tp/tp-zhuhzi-macao-bridge.htm|title=Hong Kong - Zhuhai - Macao Bridge (HZMB)|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} === Preparation === To coordinate the project, the Advance Work Coordination Group of HZMB was set up in 2003. Officials from three sides solved the issues such as landing points and alignments of the bridge, operations of the Border Crossing Facilities and project financing.{{Cite web|url=http://www.hzmb.org/en/bencandy.asp?id=2|title=Introduction to Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge - Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridg|website=www.hzmb.org|access-date=2018-10-27}} In August 2008, China's Central Government, the governments of [[Guangdong]], Hong Kong and Macau agreed to finance 42% of the total costs. The remaining 58% consisted of loans (approximately 22 billion [[Chinese yuan|yuan]] or US$ 3.23 billion) from [[Bank of China]].{{cite news |first=Mingxin |last=Bi |title=Bank of China to lead loan consortium for Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-04/14/content_11186292.htm |work=Window of China |publisher=Xinhuanet |date=14 April 2009 |accessdate=17 April 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121024042455/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-04/14/content_11186292.htm |archivedate=24 October 2012 |df=dmy-all}} In March 2009, it was further reported that China's Central Government, Hong Kong and Macau agreed to finance 22% of the total costs. The remaining 78% consisted of loans (approximately 57.3 billion yuan or US$ 8.4 billion) from a consortium of banks led by [[Bank of China]].{{cite news |first=Jonathan |last=Cheng |title=China Builds Bridge to Link Southern Cities |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB126088119555891949?mod=googlenews_wsj |work=Wall Street Journal |publisher=Dow Jones & Company |date=15 December 2009 |accessdate=15 December 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171013144446/https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB126088119555891949?mod=googlenews_wsj |archivedate=13 October 2017 |df=dmy-all}} == Construction == Construction of the HZMB project began on 15 December 2009 on the Chinese side,[[Arup Group Limited|Arup]]: [http://www.arup.com/News/2010-02_February/09_Feb_2010_Ground-breaking_HK-Zhuhai-Macao_Bridge.aspx "Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge ground breaking"]
{{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130719083538/http://www.arup.com/News/2010-02_February/09_Feb_2010_Ground-breaking_HK-Zhuhai-Macao_Bridge.aspx |date=19 July 2013 }}
19 July 2013 at the [[Wayback Machine]]. [[Category:Webarchive template wayback links]] , 9 February 2010. Retrieved 22 December 2011. with then-[[Vice Premier of China]] [[Li Keqiang]] holding a commencement ceremony. Construction of the Hong Kong section of the project began in December 2011 after a delay caused by a legal challenge regarding the environmental impact of the bridge.[[Macau Daily Times]]: [http://www.macaudailytimes.com.mo/macau/32406-Pearl-River-Delta-Bridge-work-begins.html "Pearl River Delta Bridge work begins"]
{{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120610180541/http://www.macaudailytimes.com.mo/macau/32406-Pearl-River-Delta-Bridge-work-begins.html |date=10 June 2012 }}
10 June 2012 at the [[Wayback Machine]]. [[Category:Webarchive template wayback links]] , 15 December 2011. Retrieved 22 December 2011. The last bridge tower was erected on 2 June 2016,{{cite web |url=http://en.people.cn/n3/2016/0603/c90000-9067785.html |title=HK-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge about to open to traffic |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160608012540/http://en.people.cn/n3/2016/0603/c90000-9067785.html |archivedate=8 June 2016 |df=dmy-all}}{{cite web |url=http://www.hzmb.org/en/bencandy.asp?id=3075 |title=Final HZMB Bridge Tower Erected |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161018224511/http://www.hzmb.org/en/bencandy.asp?id=3075 |archivedate=18 October 2016 |df=dmy-all}} the last straighted-element of the {{convert|4860|m|ft|adj=mid|-long}} straight section of the undersea tunnel was installed on 12 July 2016,{{cite web |url=http://en.cccchzmb.com/P29-6459.biz |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-10-14 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161018234725/http://en.cccchzmb.com/P29-6459.biz |archivedate=18 October 2016 |df=dmy-all}} while the final tunnel joint was installed on 2 May 2017. Construction of the Main Bridge, consisting of a [[viaduct]] and an undersea tunnel, was completed on 6 July 2017,{{cite web |title=Main structure of Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge is completed |url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2017-07/07/content_30035204.htm |website=China Daily |accessdate=3 October 2017 |date=7 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170720210129/http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2017-07/07/content_30035204.htm |archivedate=20 July 2017 |df=dmy-all}} and the construction of the whole project was completed on 6 February 2018.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gov.cn/xinwen/2018-02/06/content_5264425.htm|title=港珠澳大桥主体工程完成交工验收具备通车试运营条件_滚动新闻_中国政府网|last=刘淼|website=www.gov.cn|access-date=2018-10-27}} File:Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge Site HK view 201506.jpg|Hong Kong section under construction in 2015 off the coast of [[Lantau Island]] File:Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge Eastern Artificial Island 8-May-2017 02.jpg|The eastern artificial island in May 2017 File:201805 Artificial Island of HKZMBridge.jpg|The Artificial Island in May 2018 File:HK-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge HK link.jpg|The completed Hong Kong section of the bridge in November 2018 == Sections and elements == The 55-km ({{Convert|55|km|mi|abbr=on|disp=out}}) HZMB consists of three main sections: the Main Bridge ({{Convert|29.6|km|mi|abbr=on|disp=or}}) in the middle of the Pearl River estuary, the Hong Kong Link Road ({{Convert|12|km|mi|abbr=on|disp=or}}) in the east and the Zhuhai Link Road ({{Convert|13.4|km|mi|abbr=on|disp=or}}) in the west of the estuary.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/breaking-news.php?id=116030&sid=3|title=China border control at sea crossing|work=The Standard|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.hzmb.gov.hk/en/|title=Hong Kong - Zhuhai - Macao Bridge|website=www.hzmb.gov.hk|language=en|access-date=2018-10-27}} === Main Bridge === The Main Bridge, the largest part of the HZMB project, is a bridge-cum-tunnel system constructed by the mainland Chinese authorities.{{cite web |title=HZMB Main Bridge |url=http://www.hzmb.hk/eng/about_overview_01.html |publisher=[[Highways Department]] (Hong Kong) |accessdate=16 August 2018}} It connects an artificial island, housing the Boundary Crossing Facilities (BCF) for both mainland China and Macau in the west, to the Hong Kong Link Road in the east. This section includes a 22.9-km ({{Convert|22.9|km|mi|abbr=on|disp=out}}) viaduct and a 6.7-km ({{Convert|6.7|km|mi|abbr=on|disp=out}}) undersea tunnel that runs between two artificial islands. The viaduct crosses the Pearl River estuary with three cable-stayed bridges spanning between 280 and 460 metres (920 and 1,510 ft), allowing shipping traffic to pass underneath.Website of [[Transport and Housing Bureau]] ([[Hong Kong|HKSAR]]): [http://www.thb.gov.hk/eng/policy/transport/issues/cbt_3.htm "Cross boundary traffic: Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge"]
{{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100118160158/http://www.thb.gov.hk/eng/policy/transport/issues/cbt_3.htm |date=18 January 2010 }}
18 January 2010 at the [[Wayback Machine]]. [[Category:Webarchive template wayback links]] . Retrieved 22 December 2011.[[Arup Group Limited|Arup]] (a consulting company involved in the design of the bridges): [http://www.arup.com/Projects/Hong_Kong_Zhuhai_Macau_Bridge.aspx "Hong Kong–Zhuhai–Macao Bridge overview"]
{{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100115102007/http://www.arup.com/Projects/Hong_Kong_Zhuhai_Macau_Bridge.aspx|date=15 January 2010}}
15 January 2010 at the [[Wayback Machine]]. [[Category:Webarchive template wayback links]] . Retrieved 22 December 2011. === Hong Kong Link Road === Under Hong Kong jurisdiction, the Hong Kong Link Road was built by [[Highways Department|Highway Department]] to connect the Main Bridge to an artificial island housing the Hong Kong Boundary Crossing Facilities (HKBCF). This section includes a 9.4-km ({{Convert|9.4|km|mi|abbr=on|disp=out}}) viaduct, a 1-km ({{Convert|1|km|mi|abbr=on|disp=out}}) Scenic Hill Tunnel and a 1.6-km ({{Convert|1.6|km|mi|abbr=on|disp=out}}) at-grade road along the east coast of the [[Hong Kong International Airport]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.hzmb.hk/eng/about_overview_02.html|title=HongKong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge (HZMB) : Hong Kong Link Road|website=www.hzmb.hk|language=en|access-date=2018-10-27}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.news.gov.hk/eng/2018/01/20180120/20180120_113410_060.html|title=Bridge link road surfacing completed|website=Hong Kong's Information Services Department|language=en|access-date=2018-10-27}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.hyd.gov.hk/en/road_and_railway/hzmb_projects/6787th/HZM6844TH-PD0005.pdf|title=Plot of Hong Kong - Zhuhai - Macao Baridge - Hong Kong Link Road|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}} === Zhuhai Link Road === The Zhuhai Link Road starts from an artificial island housing the Boundary Crossing Facilities for both mainland China and Macau, passes through the developed area of [[Gongbei Subdistrict|Gongbei]] via a tunnel towards Zhuhai, and connects to three major expressways, namely, the [[Jingzhu Expressway|Jing-Zhu Expressway]], Guang-Zhu West Expressway and Jiang-Zhu Expressway.{{Cite web|url=http://www.hzmb.hk/eng/about_overview_06.html|title=HongKong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge (HZMB) : Connectivity to Pearl River West|website=www.hzmb.hk|language=en|access-date=2018-10-27}}{{Cite journal|last=Yeung|first=Albert|date=2016-01-29|title=Geotechnical works of the Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge Project|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/292213640_Geotechnical_works_of_the_Hong_Kong-Zhuhai-Macao_Bridge_Project|journal=Japanese Geotechnical Society Special Publication|volume=2|pages=109–121|doi=10.3208/jgssp.ESD-KL-3}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.hyd.gov.hk/en/road_and_railway/hzmb_projects/6787th/HZM6844TH-PD0005.pdf|title=Hong Kong Link Road (HKLR)|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}} == Left- and right-hand traffic == Although the HZMB connects two [[left-hand traffic]] (LHT) areas, namely Hong Kong and Macau, the crossing itself is [[right-hand traffic]] (RHT), the same as in Zhuhai and other regions of China. Thus, drivers from Hong Kong and Macau need to make use of crossing viaducts to switch to RHT upon entering the bridge, and back to LHT upon leaving the bridge when they are back to Hong Kong and Macau.{{Cite news|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2017/02/21/cars-may-drive-right-hong-kong-zhuhai-macao-bridge-despite-citys-left-hand-traffic-arrangement/|title=Cars may drive on the right on Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge, despite city's left-hand traffic arrangement {{!}} Hong Kong Free Press HKFP|date=2017-02-21|work=Hong Kong Free Press HKFP|access-date=2018-11-01|language=en-GB}}{{Cite web|url=https://html2-f.scribdassets.com/4jy6fyf98g5q0dpy/images/15-456a6791f3.png|title=Interface of "Left-driving" & "Right-driving" Arrangement|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Traffic between Zhuhai and the bridge requires no left-right conversion as they are both RHT.{{cite news |last1=Su |first1=Xinqi |last2=Yeung |first2=Raymond |title=Right side of road the only way to travel on Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau bridge |url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/economy/article/2133246/right-side-road-only-way-travel-hong-kong-zhuhai-macau-bridge |work=South China Morning Post |date=13 February 2018}} == Transport == === Shuttle buses === [[File:VR6495 at HZMB Zhuhai Port (20181024103741).jpg|thumb|Shuttle buses between Hong Kong and Zhuhai/Macau]] Shuttle buses are available 24 hours a day and depart up to every 5 minutes with tickets available for purchase from vending machines or ticket counters.{{Cite web|url=http://www.hzmbus.com|title=HZMBus|last=|first=|date=|website=www.hzmbus.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-22}} They take around 40 minutes to cross the HZMB. The HZMB Hong Kong Port can be reached from Hong Kong by taxis or various buses including [[Cityflyer (bus service)|Cityflyer]] airport (A-number) routes, or the B5 shuttle bus from Sunny Bay MTR station, or the B6 bus from [[Tung Chung]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.hzmbus.com/passenger_service.html?id=53|title=Shuttle bus services at Hong Kong Port (in Chinese)|last=|first=|date=|website=www.hzmbus.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-23}} The HZMB Zhuhai Port can be reached from the mainland by taxis or the L1 bus which uses historic tourist vehicles, or Line-12, 23, 25 or 3 buses.{{Cite web|url=http://www.hzmbus.com/passenger_service.html?id=45|title=Shuttle bus services at Zhuhai Port (in Chinese)|last=|first=|date=|website=www.hzmbus.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-23}} The HZMB Macau Port can be reached from Macau by taxis or various buses including the 101X bus and the 102X bus from St Paul's and Taipa, or the HZMB Integrated Resort Connection bus from Taipa Ferry Terminal or the Exterior Ferry terminal, connecting with free casino shuttle buses.{{Cite web|url=http://www.hzmbus.com/passenger_service.html?id=60|title=Shuttle bus services at Macau Port (in Chinese)|last=|first=|date=|website=www.hzmbus.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-23}} === Private vehicles and restrictions === Currently only 10,000 permits are available for private vehicles to drive across the HZMB from Hong Kong to Zhuhai.{{Cite news|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/economy/article/2124010/hong-kongs-bridge-zhuhai-allow-7000-extra-cars-cross-after|title=Zhuhai bridge to allow 7,000 more cars after high demand|work=South China Morning Post|access-date=2018-10-25|language=en}} In addition, the number of vehicles permitted to enter Hong Kong and Macau from other regions is subject to a daily quota.{{cite web|url=https://www.td.gov.hk/en/public_services/licences_and_permits/closed_road_permit_for_cross_boundary_vehicles/rq_hk_private_cars_to_macao_access_city_centre/index.html|title=Transport Department - Regular Quota for Hong Kong Private Cars to Macao (Access to City Centre)|website=www.td.gov.hk|accessdate=22 October 2018}} Since the Hong Kong government imposes significant fees, taxes and administrative paperwork on private car ownership and usage to deal with road congestion,{{Cite web|url=https://www.moneyhero.com.hk/blog/en/how-much-does-it-cost-to-own-a-car-in-hong-kong|title=The cost of owning a car in Hong Kong|website=www.moneyhero.com.hk|language=en-HK|access-date=2018-10-22|date=2014-11-07}} driving a car on the HZMB would incur the same restrictions as current cross-border traffic. These include applying for separate driving licences for both Hong Kong and mainland China, a Hong Kong Closed Road Permit for cross-boundary vehicles, and an Approval Notice from the Guangdong Public Security Bureau.{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.hk/en/residents/transport/crossboundary/xb_driving.htm|title=GovHK: Cross-boundary Driving|last=(www.gov.hk)|first=GovHK|website=www.gov.hk|language=en|access-date=2018-10-22}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.td.gov.hk/en/public_services/licences_and_permits/closed_road_permit_for_cross_boundary_vehicles/index.html|title=Transport Department - Closed Road Permit for Cross-boundary Vehicles|website=www.td.gov.hk|language=en|access-date=2018-10-22}} Vehicle owners also need to ensure they have the appropriate insurance coverage for the regions they are travelling to.{{cite web |title=Insurance Authority - Motor insurance for using Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge (HZMB) |url=https://www.ia.org.hk/en/infocenter/faqs/faqs_13.html |website=www.ia.org.hk |language=zh-en}} == Economic effects == The HZMB links three major cities Hong Kong, Zhuhai and Macau, which are geographically close but separated by water. With the bridge in place, travelling time between Zhuhai and Hong Kong would cut down from about four hours to 30 minutes on the road.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-45937924|title=World's longest sea crossing: Hong Kong-Zhuhai bridge opens|date=2018-10-23|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en-GB}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2017-07/07/content_30035204.htm|title=Main structure of Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge is completed[1]- Chinadaily.com.cn|last=郭凯|website=www.chinadaily.com.cn|access-date=2018-10-28}} The HZMB project is part of a [[Beijing]]-driven strategy to create an economic hub and promote the economic development of the whole area of the [[Pearl River Delta]], which is also known as Greater Bay Area.{{Cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com.my/news/regional/2018/10/23/chinas-president-launches-hong-kong-mainland-mega-bridge/|title=China's president launches Hong Kong-mainland mega bridge - ASEAN Plus {{!}} The Star Online|website=www.thestar.com.my|access-date=2018-10-27}} Hoping to leverage the bridge and create an economic zone linking the three cities, Zhuhai's [[Hengqin]] area was designated as a free trade zone in 2015.{{Cite web|url=https://asia.nikkei.com/Politics-Economy/Economy/Hong-Kong-Zhuhai-Macau-Bridge-construction-set-to-finish-this-year|title=Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge construction set to finish this year|website=Nikkei Asian Review|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-10-28}} == Controversies == === Delays and budget overruns === The artificial island housing the Hong Kong Boundary Crossing Facilities (HKBCF) was reported drifting due to an unconventional method, hitherto unused in Hong Kong, for land reclamation with steel circular cells in a row pushed through the mud and filled with inert material to form a seawall.{{cite web|url=http://www.hzmb.hk/eng/doc/BCF%20Newsletter%20Issue%201%20E-A4.pdf|title=Newsletter 2012 July|date=July 2012|website=Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge and Related Hong Kong Projects|publisher=Highways Department|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151126121032/http://www.hzmb.hk/eng/doc/BCF%20Newsletter%20Issue%201%20E-A4.pdf|archivedate=26 November 2015|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}} The drifting of parts of the reclaimed island had allegedly caused a delay in the HZMB project. The Highways Department denied reports in various sources of movement up to 20 metres but admitted parts of the reclaimed land had moved "up to six or seven metres",{{cite news|url=http://www.ejinsight.com/20150923-island-drift-threatens-further-delays-in-cross-border-bridge/|title=Island drift threatens further delays in cross-border bridge|date=23 September 2015|work=Hong Kong Economic Journal|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151126120958/http://www.ejinsight.com/20150923-island-drift-threatens-further-delays-in-cross-border-bridge/|archivedate=26 November 2015|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2015/11/25/delays-of-up-to-5-years-for-hk30bn-moving-macau-bridge-crossing-facilities/|title=Delays of up to 5 years for HK$30bn ‘moving’ Macau bridge crossing facilities|last1=Winn|first1=Howard|date=25 November 2015|work=Hong Kong Free Press|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151126102937/https://www.hongkongfp.com/2015/11/25/delays-of-up-to-5-years-for-hk30bn-moving-macau-bridge-crossing-facilities/|archivedate=26 November 2015|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1860898/seven-metre-drift-hong-kong-artificial-island-reclaimed-bridge|title=Seven-metre drift on Hong Kong artificial island reclaimed for bridge project is normal, say officials|last1=Siu|first1=Phila|date=24 September 2015|work=South China Morning Post|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151119185623/http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1860898/seven-metre-drift-hong-kong-artificial-island-reclaimed-bridge|archivedate=19 November 2015|deadurl=no|last2=Lee|first2=Eddie|df=dmy-all}} claiming that some movement was expected and safety had not been jeopardised.{{cite news|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/article/1861223/shifting-sands-flaws-blamed-problems-artificial-island-hong-kong-zhuhai-macau|title=Shifting sands: 'flaws' blamed for problems at artificial island for Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau bridge|last1=Ng|first1=Kang-chung|date=25 September 2015|work=South China Morning Post|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151130023339/http://www.scmp.com/news/article/1861223/shifting-sands-flaws-blamed-problems-artificial-island-hong-kong-zhuhai-macau|archivedate=30 November 2015|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}} Mainland contractors were also reportedly having difficulty in constructing immersed tubes in their section of the project, with the director of the Guangdong National Development and Reform Commission stating that 2020 would be a difficult target to meet. In 2017, the Main Bridge of the HZMB project experienced a cost overrun of about 10 billion yuan, arising from an increase in labor and material costs, as well as the refinement of the design and construction schemes.{{cite web|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2017/11/22/china-stretch-hong-kong-zhuhai-macao-bridge-hits-another-budget-overrun-totalling-hk11-7-billion/|title=China stretch of Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge hits another budget overrun totalling HK$11.7 billion|date=2017-11-22|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171206161803/https://www.hongkongfp.com/2017/11/22/china-stretch-hong-kong-zhuhai-macao-bridge-hits-another-budget-overrun-totalling-hk11-7-billion/|archivedate=6 December 2017|deadurl=no|accessdate=2017-12-06|df=dmy-all}} === Worker deaths and injuries === The number of deaths and injuries that have taken place on the project has come under scrutiny in Hong Kong. Apart from nine fatal cases on the mainland side,{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-45937924|title=China opens longest sea-crossing bridge|date=2018-10-23|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en-GB}} there have been ten deaths reported on the Hong Kong side of the construction project, and somewhere between 234 and 600 injuries, depending on the source.{{cite news|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2017/04/11/lawmakers-slam-govt-misleading-death-rates-related-hk-zhuhai-macau-bridge-project/|title=Lawmakers slam gov’t over ‘misleading’ death rates related to HK-Zhuhai-Macau bridge project|last1=Ng|first1=Ellie|date=11 April 2017|work=Hong Kong Free Press|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170413235316/https://www.hongkongfp.com/2017/04/11/lawmakers-slam-govt-misleading-death-rates-related-hk-zhuhai-macau-bridge-project/|archivedate=13 April 2017|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}} In April 2017, the Construction Site Workers General Union, the [[Labour Party (Hong Kong)|Labour Party]] and the [[Hong Kong Confederation of Trade Unions|Confederation of Trade Unions]] demonstrated at the [[Central Government Complex]], demanding the government take action.{{cite news|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2017/04/12/govt-regrets-fatalities-hong-kong-zhuhai-macau-bridge-project-workers-demand-halt-murders/|title=Gov’t ‘regrets’ fatalities at Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau bridge project, as workers demand halt to ‘murders’|last1=Ng|first1=Ellie|date=12 April 2017|work=Hong Kong Free Press|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170414080754/https://www.hongkongfp.com/2017/04/12/govt-regrets-fatalities-hong-kong-zhuhai-macau-bridge-project-workers-demand-halt-murders/|archivedate=14 April 2017|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}} Lawmaker [[Fernando Cheung]] also expressed concerns over the unknown death toll on the Chinese side of the project, stating: "the project is known as the 'bridge of blood and tears’ and we are only talking about the Hong Kong side. We don’t even know what is happening in China. I suppose the situation could be 10 times worse than that in Hong Kong." He said that the Hong Kong Government had a responsibility to consider worker safety on the Chinese side. === Faked safety testing === In 2017, Hong Kong's [[Independent Commission Against Corruption (Hong Kong)|Independent Commission Against Corruption]] (ICAC) arrested 21 employees (two senior executives, 14 laboratory technicians and five laboratory assistants) of Jacobs China Limited, a contractor of the Civil Engineering and Development Department for falsifying concrete test results, thus potentially risking the safety of bridge for public use.{{cite news|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2017/05/24/arrests-fake-lab-tests-mega-bridge-project-damages-trust-govt-lawmakers-warn/|title=‘Fake’ lab tests at mega bridge project damage trust in gov’t, lawmakers warn|last1=Ng|first1=Ellie|date=24 May 2017|work=Hong Kong Free Press}} In December 2017, a lab technician pleaded guilty and was sentenced to imprisonment for eight months, while the others await sentencing. Hong Kong's Highways Department conducted tests again after the falsified results were exposed and found all test results met safety standards.{{cite news|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2017/12/01/lab-technician-jailed-8-months-falsifying-hong-kong-zhuhai-macao-bridge-test-records/|title=Lab technician jailed for 8 months after falsifying Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao bridge test records|last1=Cheng|first1=Kris|date=1 December 2017|work=Hong Kong Free Press}} === Seawall integrity === In April 2018, the public and media raised questions over the integrity of the seawalls protecting the artificial islands at both ends of the undersea tunnel. In footage taken by drone users and mariners, the [[dolos]]se installed at the edges of the artificial islands appear to have dislodged. Some civil engineers suggested that there was an error in design.{{cite news|url=https://lantaunews.com/2018/04/05/this-weeks-bridge-problem-tunnels-face-flooding-threat/|title=This week’s bridge problem: tunnel faces flooding threat|last1=Clark|first1=Robert|date=5 April 2018|work=Lantau News}}{{cite news|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2018/04/03/hk-zhuhai-macao-bridge-components-found-drifting-artificial-island-authority-claims-may-illusion/|title=HK-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge components found drifting from artificial island, as authority claims it may be an ‘illusion’|last1=Cheng|first1=Kris|date=3 April 2018|work=[[Hong Kong Free Press]]}} In dismissing the safety concerns, the HZMB Authority said the dolosse were designed to be submerged and the design was working as intended.{{Cite news|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/2140330/safety-concerns-over-artificial-island-mega-hong-kong-zhuhai|title=Drifting away? Concerns over Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau bridge dismissed|work=South China Morning Post|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en}} Director of [[Highways Department]] Daniel Chung denied on 8 April 2018 that the breakwater components had been washed away by waves.{{Cite news|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2018/04/10/hong-kong-zhuhai-macao-bridge-breakwater-design-scientific-reasonable-safe-says-top-govt-official/|title=Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge breakwater design scientific, reasonable and safe, says top gov't official {{!}} Hong Kong Free Press HKFP|date=2018-04-10|work=Hong Kong Free Press HKFP|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en-GB}} Subsequent aerial footage posted online showed a section of the dolosse breakwater completely underwater. Civil engineer So Yiu-kwan told Hong Kong media on 12 April 2018 that the water level, at the time the photos were taken, was about 1.74 mPD (metres above Principal Datum), but the maximum water level could reach 2.7 mPD. He said the dolosse would offer no wave protection if entirely submerged, and further alleged that they had been installed backwards.{{cite news|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2018/04/12/sea-bridge-islands-breakwater-blocks-offer-no-protection-underwater-high-tide-says-veteran-engineer/|title=Sea bridge island’s breakwater blocks offer no protection as they are underwater at high tide, says veteran engineer|last1=Cheng|first1=Kris|date=12 April 2018|work=Hong Kong Free Press}} ===Falling number of dolphins=== Conservationists at [[WWF Hong Kong]] blamed the construction of the HZMB for the falling number of [[Sousa chinensis|white dolphins]] in the waters near the bridge. The dolphins found near waters of [[Lantau]] were worst hit with numbers dropping by 60 per cent between April 2015 and March 2016.{{cite news |title=Experts blame Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge for falling dolphin numbers |url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/1990312/experts-blame-hong-kong-zhuhai-macau-bridge |accessdate=28 October 2018 |agency=SCMP}} == See also == {{portal|Bridges|China|Hong Kong|Macau}} * [[Environment of China]] * [[Ecology of Hong Kong|Environment of Hong Kong]] * [[Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area]] * [[Transport in China]] * revision.text:
{{distinguish|Human nature}} {{Other uses}} The '''human condition''' is "the characteristics, key events, and situations which compose the essentials of [[human]] existence, such as birth, growth, emotionality, aspiration, conflict, and mortality".<ref>"[[wikt:human condition|human condition]]" entry at [[Wiktionary]]</ref> This is a very broad topic which has been and continues to be pondered and analyzed from many perspectives, including those of [[religion]], [[philosophy]], [[history]], [[art]], [[literature]], [[anthropology]], [[psychology]], and [[biology]].
As a [[terminology|literary term]], "the human condition" is typically used in the context of ambiguous subjects such as the [[meaning of life]] or [[morality|moral concerns]].<ref name="lit">[http://learn.lexiconic.net/humancondition.htm The human condition in literature]</ref>
==Some perspectives==
Each [[major religious groups|major religion]] has definitive beliefs regarding the human condition. For example, [[Buddhism]] [[Four Noble Truths|teaches]] that life is a perpetual cycle of [[dukkha|suffering]], death, and rebirth from which humans can be liberated via the [[Noble Eightfold Path]]. Meanwhile, [[Christianity]] teaches that humans are born in a [[original sin|sinful condition]] and are [[Christian views on hell|doomed]] in the [[afterlife]] unless they receive [[Salvation (Christianity)|salvation]] through [[Jesus|Jesus Christ]].
Philosophers have provided many perspectives. An influential ancient view was that of the ''[[The Republic (Plato)|Republic]]'' in which [[Plato]] explored the question "what is justice?" and postulated that it is not primarily a matter among individuals but of [[society]] as a whole, prompting him to devise a [[utopia]]. Two thousand years later [[René Descartes]] declared "[[Cogito ergo sum|I think, therefore I am]]" because he believed the human mind, particularly its faculty of [[reason]], to be the primary determiner of [[truth]]; for this he is often credited as the father of modern philosophy.<ref>[[Bertrand Russell]] (2004) [https://books.google.com/books?id=Ey94E3sOMA0C&pg=PA511 ''History of Western Philosophy''] pp.511, 516–7</ref> One such modern school, [[existentialism]], attempts to reconcile an individual's sense of disorientation and confusion in a universe believed to be [[absurdism|absurd]].
Many works of literature provide perspective on the human condition.<ref name="lit"/> One famous example is [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare's]] monologue "[[All the world's a stage]]" that pensively summarizes seven phases of human life.
Psychology has many theories, such as [[Maslow's hierarchy of needs]] and the notion of [[identity crisis]]. It also has various methods, e.g. the [[logotherapy]] developed by [[The Holocaust|Holocaust]] survivor [[Viktor Frankl]] to discover and affirm human meaning. Another method, [[cognitive behavioral therapy]], has become a widespread treatment for [[major depressive disorder|clinical depression]].<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Driessen Ellen |author2=Hollon Steven D | year = 2010 | title = Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Mood Disorders: Efficacy, Moderators and Mediators | url = | journal = Psychiatric Clinics of North America | volume = 33 | issue = 3| pages = 537–55 | doi=10.1016/j.psc.2010.04.005 | pmid=20599132 | pmc=2933381}}</ref>
Ever since 1859, when [[Charles Darwin]] published ''[[On the Origin of Species]]'', the biological [[scientific theory|theory]] of [[evolution]] has been significant. The theory posits that the human [[species]] is related to all others, living and extinct, and that [[natural selection]] is the primary survival factor. This has provided a basis for new beliefs, e.g. [[social Darwinism]], and for new [[technology]], e.g. [[antibiotics]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Gladki A, Kaczanowski S, Szczesny P, Zielenkiewicz P |title=The evolutionary rate of antibacterial drug targets |journal=BMC Bioinformatics |volume=14 |pages=36 |date=February 2013 |pmid=23374913 |url= |doi=10.1186/1471-2105-14-36 |pmc=3598507}}</ref>
==Use of the term==
Notable uses of the term "the human condition" include [[André Malraux]]'s novel ''[[Man's Fate]]'', [[René Magritte]]'s painting ''[[The Human Condition (painting)|La Condition Humaine]]'', [[Hannah Arendt]]'s [[The Human Condition (book)|political philosophy]], and [[Masaki Kobayashi]]'s [[The Human Condition (film series)|film trilogy]].
==See also== * [[Human nature]] * [[Human self-reflection]]
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Human Condition}} [[Category:Existentialist concepts]] [[Category:Personal life]] [[Category:Philosophy of life]] [[Category:Humans]]

[[Image:Iceland A2003247 1410.jpg|thumb|250px|An Icelandic cyclone on September 4, 2003]]
The '''Icelandic Low''' is a semi-permanent centre of low [[atmospheric pressure]] found between [[Iceland]] and southern [[Greenland]] and extending in the [[Northern Hemisphere]] winter into the [[Barents Sea]]. In summer it weakens and splits into two centres, one near [[Davis Strait]] and the other west of Iceland. It is a principal centre of action in the atmosphere circulation of the Northern Hemisphere, associated with frequent [[cyclone]] activity. It forms one pole of the [[North Atlantic oscillation]], the other being the [[Azores High]].
==See also== *[[Kona low]] *[[Aleutian low]]
==References== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050208192303/http://nsidc.org/arcticmet/glossary/icelandic_low.html National Snow and Ice Data Center], retrieved 19 May 2005.

revision.text:
{{Infobox rockunit | name = John Day Strata | image = Blue basin lower trail.jpg | caption = Exposures of the Turtle Cove Formation along a hiking trail in the Sheep Rock Unit of the John Day Fossil Beds National Monument | type = Sedimentary (mostly from clasts of igneous origin), igneous | age = [[Eocene]]-[[Miocene|Early Miocene]] | period = Miocene | prilithology = [[Sandstone]], [[tuff]] | otherlithology = [[pyroclastic rock|Pyroclastic]] | namedfor = [[John Day River]] | namedby = | region = [[Central Oregon]] | country = United States | coordinates = | unitof = | subunits = | underlies = [[Columbia River Basalt Group]] | overlies = [[Clarno Formation]] | thickness = | extent = | area = | map = | map_caption = }} The '''John Day Formation''' is a series of rock strata exposed in the Picture Gorge district of the [[John Day River]] basin and elsewhere in north-central [[Oregon]] in the United States. The Picture Gorge exposure lies east of the [[Blue Mountains (Oregon)|Blue Mountain]] uplift, which cuts southwest–northeast through the [[Horse Heaven, Oregon|Horse Heaven]] mining district northeast of [[Madras, Oregon|Madras]]. Aside from the Picture Gorge district, which [[Type site|defines the type]], the formation is visible on the surface in two other areas: another exposure is in the Warm Springs district west of the uplift, between it and the [[Cascade Range]], and the third is along the south side of the [[Ochoco Mountains]]. All three exposures, consisting mainly of [[tuff]]aceous sediments and [[pyroclastic rock|pyroclastic]] rock rich in [[silicon dioxide|silica]], lie [[Unconformity|unconformably]] between the older rocks of the Clarno Formation below and [[Columbia River Basalt Group|Columbia River basalts]] above.<ref name="Woodburne and Robinson">{{cite journal|last1=Woodburne|first1=M.O.|last2=Robinson,|first2=P.T.|title=A New Late Hemingfordian Mammal Fauna from the John Day Formation, Oregon, and its Stratigraphic Implications|date=July 1977|journal=Journal of Paleontology|volume=51|issue=4|pages=750–57|publisher = The Society of Economic Paleontologists and Mineralogists|jstor=1303741|subscription=yes}}</ref>
== Stratigraphy == The strata, which vary in age from 39 million years to 18 million years, were formed mainly from ashfalls from volcanoes due to a series of calderas now linked to the Yellowstone hotspot. Some of the major layers within the group exposed in the Picture Gorge district are the [[Big Basin Formation]] and Bridge Creek Beds (35 to 32 million years), the [[Turtle Cove Formation]] (30 to 28 million years), the [[Picture Gorge Ignimbrite]] (28.7 million years), the [[Kimberly Formation]] (28 to 25 million years), and the [[Haystack Formation]] (25 to 18 million years).<ref name="OPLI">{{cite web|title=The Geologic Formations of the John Day Basin |url=http://www.paleolands.org/pdf/REGIONALGEOLOGY.pdf|publisher=Oregon Paleo Lands Institute|accessdate=September 23, 2011}}</ref>
Located in the general vicinity of what became the Cascade Range, the John Day volcanoes emitted large volumes of ash and dust, much of which settled in the John Day basin. The rapid deposition of the ash preserved the remains of plants and animals living in the region. Some of the solidified ash and the fossils they contain are found in the [[John Day Fossil Beds National Monument]]. Because ash and other debris fell during varied climatic and volcanic conditions and accumulated from many eruptions extending into the early [[Miocene]] (about 20 million years ago), the sediment layers in the fossil beds vary in their chemical composition and color.<ref name="Orr 30-31"/> The lowermost layer contains red ash, such as that exposed in the Painted Hills Unit of the national monument.<ref>Orr, pp. 30–31, 46</ref> The layer above it is mainly pea-green clay. On top of the pea-green layer are buff-colored layers.<ref name="Orr 30-31">Orr, pp. 30–31</ref>
== Paleontology == Fossils found in the John Day Formation include a wide variety of plants and more than 100 species of mammals, including dogs, cats, [[oreodont]]s, horses, camels, and rodents.<ref name="geology fieldnotes">{{cite web|title=Geology Fieldnotes|publisher=National Park Service|url=http://www.nature.nps.gov/geology/parks/joda/#geology|accessdate=July 25, 2011}}</ref> Among the notable plant fossils are ''[[Metasequoia]]'' (Dawn Redwood), a [[genus]] thought to have gone extinct worldwide until it was discovered alive in China in the early twentieth century.<ref>Orr, p. 46</ref>
{{wide image|East face painted hills panorama.jpg|1100px|Panorama of some of the John Day Formation strata exposed in the Painted Hills Unit of the John Day Fossil Beds National Monument}}

=== Bibliography === * Orr, Elizabeth L., and Orr, William N. (1999). ''Geology of Oregon'', 5th ed. Dubuque, Iowa: Kendall/Hunt Publishing Company. {{ISBN|0-7872-6608-6}}.

revision.text:
{{multiple issues|{{COI|date=March 2017}} {{news release|1=article|date=March 2017}}}} {{Infobox organization | name = Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security | native_name = | native_name_lang = | named_after = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map2 = | map2_size = | map2_alt = | map2_caption = | abbreviation = CHS<ref name="open_phil" /> | motto = | predecessor = | merged = | successor = | formation = {{start date and age|1998}}<ref name="open_phil" /> | founder = | founding_location = | extinction = <!-- use {{end date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | merger = | type = [[Think tank]] | tax_id = <!-- or | vat_id = (for European organizations) --> | registration_id = <!-- for non-profit org --> | status = | purpose = | headquarters = | location = [[Baltimore]], [[Maryland]], [[United States of America]] | coords = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|display=inline, title}} --> | region = | services = | products = | methods = | fields = | membership = | membership_year = | language = | owner = <!-- or | owners = --> | sec_gen = | leader_title = [[Chief Executive Officer|CEO]] and Director | leader_name = Tom Inglesby | leader_title2 = [[Chief Operating Officer|COO]] and Deputy Director | leader_name2 = Anita Cicero | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | board_of_directors = | key_people = {{unbulleted list|[[D. A. Henderson]]|[[Tara O'Toole]]}} | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | secessions = | affiliations = [[Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health]] | budget = | budget_year = | revenue = | revenue_year = | disbursements = | expenses = | expenses_year = | endowment = | staff = 23<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.centerforhealthsecurity.org/our-staff/profiles/index.html |author=Teddy Karambelas |date=January 26, 2017 |title=Our Staff |accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref> | staff_year = 2017 | volunteers = | volunteers_year = | slogan = | mission = "Protect people's health from the consequences of epidemics and disasters and ensure that communities are resilient to major challenges."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.centerforhealthsecurity.org/ |author=Teddy Karambelas |date=February 7, 2017 |title=JHSPH Center for Health Security |accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref> | website = {{URL|http://www.centerforhealthsecurity.org/}} | remarks = | formerly = {{unbulleted list|Johns Hopkins Center for Civilian Biodefense Strategies (1998–2003)|Center for Biosecurity of UPMC (2003–2013)|UPMC Center for Health Security (2013–2017)}} | footnotes = }} The '''Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security''' (abbreviated '''CHS'''; previously the '''UPMC Center for Health Security''',<ref name="jh_rename">{{cite web |url=http://www.centerforhealthsecurity.org/our-work/events/JHSPH%20Partnership/JHSPH%20Partnership |author=Price Tyson |date=January 16, 2017 |title=Center for Health Security Joins Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School |publisher=Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security |accessdate=February 8, 2017 |quote=the Center for Health Security, which had previously been affiliated with the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center (UPMC), has joined the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health.}}</ref> the '''Center for Biosecurity of UPMC''', and the '''Johns Hopkins Center for Civilian Biodefense Strategies''') is an independent, nonprofit organization of the [[Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health]] that works in the area of health consequences from epidemics and disasters. It is a [[think tank]] that does policy research and gives policy recommendations to the [[United States government]].<ref name=about>[http://www.upmchealthsecurity.org/website/about_us/ Center for Health Security] Mission Statement {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130622081819/http://www.upmchealthsecurity.org/website/about_us/ |date=June 22, 2013 }}</ref><ref name="open_phil" />
==History==
The Center for Health Security began as the Johns Hopkins Center for Civilian Biodefense Strategies (CCBS) in 1998 at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health.<ref name="roos" /> [[D. A. Henderson]] served as the founding director.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.centerforhealthsecurity.org/our-staff/profiles/henderson/index.html |author=UPMC Center for Health Security |date=January 18, 2017 |title=D. A. Henderson |accessdate=February 10, 2017 |quote=He was Dean Emeritus and Professor at the Johns Hopkins School of Public Health and a Founding Director (1998) of the Johns Hopkins Center for Civilian Biodefense Strategies.}}</ref> At that time, the Center was the first and only academic center focused on biosecurity policy and practice.
At one point around 2003, CHS had become part of a new [[umbrella organization]] called the Institute for Global Health and Security at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health.<ref name="roos" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://pages.jh.edu/~gazette/2003/22sep03/22global.html |title=Public Health forms Global Health, Security Institute |publisher=''Johns Hopkins Gazette'' |date=September 22, 2003 |accessdate=February 10, 2017 |first=Tim |last=Parsons}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jhsph.edu/news/news-releases/2003/global-health-security.html |author=JH Bloomberg School of Public Health |date=September 16, 2003 |title=Institute for Global Health and Security |publisher=Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health |accessdate=February 10, 2017}}</ref>
In November 2003, the leaders left Johns Hopkins to join the [[University of Pittsburgh Medical Center]] (UPMC), and relaunched the Center as the Center for Biosecurity of UPMC. This move apparently split the organization in two, and it is unclear what happened to the old organization.<ref name="roos">{{cite web |url=http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2003/09/johns-hopkins-biodefense-experts-head-new-direction |first=Robert |last=Roos|publisher=CIDRAP |title=Johns Hopkins biodefense experts head in new direction |accessdate=February 8, 2017 |date=September 23, 2003 |quote=the four full-time faculty members and 16 administrative staff members of the CCBS are all leaving Hopkins to join the UPMC. 'No decision has been made exactly what to do with the Center for Civilian Biodefense Strategies, whether it'll have a new direction or mission incorporated into some other center,' [Tim Parsons] said. 'But its biodefense activities will be incorporated in some way into the new initiative of the Institute for Global Health Security.'}}</ref>
On April 30, 2013, the Center changed its name from "Center for Biosecurity of UPMC" to "UPMC Center for Health Security". This name change reflected a broadening of the scope of CHS's work.
In January 2017, the Center became part of the [[Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health]]. Its [[domain name]] changed from upmchealthsecurity.org to centerforhealthsecurity.org.<ref name="jh_rename" />
==Funding==
In 2002, the Center received a $1 million grant from the US federal government.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jhsph.edu/news/news-releases/2002/biodefense-grant.html |date=January 7, 2002 |title=Biodefense Center to Receive $1 Million |author=JH Bloomberg School of Public Health |publisher=Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health |accessdate=February 10, 2017}}</ref>
Before 2017, CHS was heavily reliant on government funding.<ref name="open_phil" />
In January 2017, the [[Open Philanthropy Project]] awarded a $16 million grant over three years to the Center for Health Security.<ref name="open_phil">{{cite web |url=http://www.openphilanthropy.org/focus/global-catastrophic-risks/biosecurity/center-health-security-biosecurity-global-health-security-and-global-catastrophic |title=Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security — Biosecurity, Global Health Security, and Global Catastrophic Risks |publisher= Open Philanthropy Project |accessdate=February 8, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://thedailyrecord.com/2017/02/08/maryland-health-security-grant-hopkins/ |title=Hopkins' Center for Health Security gets $16M grant |publisher=Maryland Daily Record |author=Associated Press |date=February 8, 2017 |accessdate=February 8, 2017 |quote=The Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health's Center for Health Security has been awarded a three-year, $16 million grant to support work on strengthening health security and public health preparedness.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2017/feb/8/center-for-health-security-gets-16m-grant/ |publisher=''[[The Washington Times]]'' |title=Center for Health Security gets $16M grant |date=February 8, 2017 |accessdate=February 8, 2017}}</ref>
==Publications==
The Center for Health Security publishes three online newsletters:
* ''Clinicians' Biosecurity News'' (formerly the ''Clinicians' Biosecurity Network Report''), published twice each month<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.upmc-cbn.org/about_cbn/about_network.html |author=Center for Biosecurity of UPMC |date=January 16, 2017 |title=About Clinicians' Biosecurity News |publisher=UPMC Center for Health Security |accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref> * ''Health Security Headlines'', a daily news digest<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.centerforhealthsecurity.org/resources/hsh/index.html |author=Center for Biosecurity of UPMC |date=January 31, 2017 |title=Health Security Headlines |accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref> (previously called ''Biosecurity Briefing'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upmc-biosecurity.org/website/biosecurity_briefing |author=Center for Biosecurity of UPMC |title=Biosecurity Briefing |date=September 21, 2007 |accessdate=February 10, 2017 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927021007/http://www.upmc-biosecurity.org/website/biosecurity_briefing |archivedate=September 27, 2007 |df= }}</ref> then ''Biosecurity News in Brief'' starting in 2009,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upmc-biosecurity.org/website/biosecurity_briefing/ |author=Center for Biosecurity of UPMC |title=Biosecurity News in Brief -- Center for Biosecurity of UPMC |date=April 30, 2009 |accessdate=February 10, 2017 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090501170510/http://www.upmc-biosecurity.org/website/biosecurity_briefing/ |archivedate=May 1, 2009 |df= }}</ref> then ''Biosecurity News Today'' starting in 2010 or 2011,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upmc-biosecurity.org/website/biosecurity_briefing |author=Center for Biosecurity of UPMC |date=July 15, 2011 |title=Biosecurity News Today |accessdate=February 10, 2017 |quote=Biosecurity News Today |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717134042/http://www.upmc-biosecurity.org/website/biosecurity_briefing |archivedate=July 17, 2011 |df= }}</ref> and finally ''Health Security Headlines'' starting in 2013;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upmc-biosecurity.org/website/biosecurity_briefing/ |author=Center for Biosecurity of UPMC |date=August 13, 2012 |title=Center for Biosecurity {{!}} UPMC {{!}} Biosecurity News Today |accessdate=February 10, 2017 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130206192754/http://www.upmc-biosecurity.org/website/biosecurity_briefing/ |archivedate=February 6, 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upmchealthsecurity.org/website/health-security-headlines/ |author=Center for Biosecurity of UPMC |date=July 1, 2013 |title=Health Security Headlines {{!}} Published by UPMC Center for Health Security |accessdate=February 10, 2017 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130711042710/http://www.upmchealthsecurity.org/website/health-security-headlines/ |archivedate=July 11, 2013 |df= }}</ref> the digest used to also be weekly until in February 2009)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://incaseofemergencyblog.com/2009/02/05/weekly-biosecurity-briefing-e-newsletter-is-becoming-a-daily/ |title=Weekly "Biosecurity Briefing" E-Newsletter Is Becoming A Daily |website=In Case Of Emergency, Read Blog |first=John |last=Solomon |date=February 5, 2009 |accessdate=February 10, 2017 |quote=I am happy to report that a helpful weekly email resource is going daily beginning this Monday. The ''Biosecurity Briefing'', published by the Baltimore-based Center for Biosecurity of the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, is being expanded.}}</ref> * ''Preparedness Pulsepoints'', published weekly<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.centerforhealthsecurity.org/resources/pulsepoints/index.html |author=Center for Biosecurity of UPMC |date=January 31, 2017 |title=Preparedness Pulsepoints |accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref>
It also provides editorial oversight for the journal ''Health Security'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.centerforhealthsecurity.org/our-work/index.html |author=Rob Adams |date=January 18, 2017 |title=Our Work |accessdate=February 9, 2017 |quote=Journal: The Center provides editorial oversight for the peer-reviewed journal, Health Security, which is published 6 times per year.}}</ref> which was launched in 2003 and called ''Biosecurity and Bioterrorism: Biodefense Strategy, Practice, and Science'' until 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://online.liebertpub.com/bsp |title=Biosecurity and Bioterrorism: Biodefense Strategy, Practice, and Science {{!}} Issue List |accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref>
CHS also publishes the [[blog]] ''The Bifurcated Needle''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bifurcatedneedle.com/about/ |publisher=Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security |website=The Bifurcated Needle |title=About |accessdate=February 10, 2017}}</ref>
The Open Philanthropy Project's grant writeup of CHS noted several publications:<ref name="open_phil" />
* {{Cite journal| doi = 10.1126/science.aab0713| issn = 0036-8075| volume = 349| issue = 6250| pages = 792–793| last1 = Boddie| first1 = Crystal| last2 = Watson| first2 = Matthew| last3 = Ackerman| first3 = Gary| last4 = Gronvall| first4 = Gigi Kwik| title = Assessing the bioweapons threat: Is there a foundation of agreement among experts about risk?| journal = Science| date = August 21, 2015| url = http://www.upmchealthsecurity.org/our-work/pubs_archive/pubs-pdfs/2015/Science2015Boddie7923_1.pdf | pmid = 26293941}} * {{Cite journal| doi = 10.15252/embr.201541674| issn = 1469-3178| volume = 17| issue = 2| pages = 127–130| last1 = Inglesby| first1 = Thomas V.| last2 = Relman| first2 = David A.| title = How likely is it that biological agents will be used deliberately to cause widespread harm?| journal = EMBO Reports| date = February 1, 2016| url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.15252/embr.201541674/abstract| pmc = 5290809}} * {{Cite web|url=http://www.upmchealthsecurity.org/our-work/pubs_archive/pubs-pdfs/2016/Final_report_to_PASCC_071416.pdf |title=Improving Security through International Biosafety Norms |first1=Gigi Kwik |last1=Gronvall|first2=Matthew|last2= Shearer|first3= Hannah|last3= Collins|first4= Thomas|last4= Inglesby |date=July 14, 2016 |publisher=UPMC Center for Health Security}}
The Center has published in journals including ''[[JAMA (journal)|JAMA]]'' and ''[[The Lancet]]''. A full list of publications is available on the CHS website. {{as of|2017|02}}, the list shows more than 400 publications.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.centerforhealthsecurity.org/our-work/publications/?resultCount=9999&view=list |title=All Publications |accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref>
==Major conferences and events==
===Clade X===
On May 15, 2018, the Center hosted [http://www.centerforhealthsecurity.org/our-work/events/2018_clade_x_exercise/index.html Clade X], a day-long pandemic tabletop exercise that simulated a series of National Security Council–convened meetings of 10 US government leaders, played by individuals prominent in the fields of national security or epidemic response.
Drawing from actual events, Clade X identified important policy issues and preparedness challenges that could be solved with sufficient political will and attention. These issues were designed in a narrative to engage and educate the participants and the audience.
Clade X was [http://www.centerforhealthsecurity.org/our-work/events/2018_clade_x_exercise/livestream livestreamed] on Facebook and extensive materials from the exercise [http://www.centerforhealthsecurity.org/our-work/events/2018_clade_x_exercise/clade-x-resources are available online].
===Atlantic Storm===
On January 14, 2005, CHS helped to host [[Atlantic Storm]], a table-top [[smallpox]] [[bioterrorism]] simulation.<ref name="open_phil" />
===Operation Dark Winter===
From June 22–23, 2001, CHS co-hosted [[Operation Dark Winter]], a senior-level bioterrorism attack simulation involving a covert and widespread smallpox attack on the United States.
===Other===
{{Div col|colwidth=30em}} *Improving Epidemic Response: Building Bridges Between the US and China. May 2012. *Considerations for the Reauthorization of the Pandemic and All-Hazards Preparedness Act (PAHPA). March 2012. *U.S. Preparedness for a Nuclear Detonation. October 2011. *Charting the Future of Biosecurity: Ten Years After the Anthrax Attacks. October 2011. *Advancing US Resilience to a Nuclear Catastrophe. May 2011. *Preserving National Security: The Growing Role of the Life Sciences. March 2011. *Improving Global Health, Strengthening Global Security. November 2010. *The State of BIOPreparedness: Lessons from Leaders, Proposals for Progress. September 2010. *Preparing to Save Lives and Recover After a Nuclear Detonation: Implications for US Policy. April 2010. *The 2009 H1N1 Experience: Policy Implications for Future Infectious Disease Emergencies. March 2010. *Resilient American Communities: Progress In Practice and Policy. December 10, 2009. *Prevention of Biothreats: A Look Ahead. October 6, 2009. *Disease, Disaster, and Democracy: The Public's Stake in Health Emergency Planning. May 2006. *Bulls, Bears, and Birds: Preparing the Financial Industry for a Pandemic. September 2005. *Conference on Biosafety and Biorisks. May 2005. *The Public as an Asset, Not a Problem: A Summit on Leadership During Bioterrorism. February 2003. *2nd National Symposium on Medical and Public Health Response to Bioterrorism. November 2000. *National Symposium on Medical and Public Health Response to Bioterrorism. February 1999. {{Div col end}}
==See also==
{{Div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[Alfred P. Sloan Foundation]] * [[Anti-terrorism legislation]] * [[Biological Weapons Anti-Terrorism Act of 1989]] * [[Biological Weapons Convention]] * [[Cartagena Protocol on Biosafety]] * [[Center for Strategic and International Studies]] * [[Convention on Biological Diversity]] * [[Council of Europe Convention on the Prevention of Terrorism]] * [[European BioSafety Association]] * [[European Programme for Intervention Epidemiology Training]] * ''[[Eurosurveillance]]'' * [[Global catastrophic risk]] * [[Global Health Security Initiative]] * [[Health Threat Unit]] * [[International Health Regulations]] * [[Johns Hopkins Berman Institute of Bioethics]] * [[Office of the Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response]] * [[Open Philanthropy Project#Biosecurity|Open Philanthropy Project § Biosecurity]] * [[Pandemic and All-Hazards Preparedness Reauthorization Act of 2013]] * [[Public Health Emergency Preparedness]] * [[PublicHealthEmergency.gov]] {{Div col end}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.centerforhealthsecurity.org/}} * [http://www.bifurcatedneedle.com/ ''The Bifurcated Needle''], the Center for Health Security's blog * [http://www.upmc-cbn.org/index.html ''Clinicians' Biosecurity News''], a twice monthly newsletter published by the Center * [http://www.liebertpub.com/hs ''Health Security''] * [http://www.liebertonline.com/loi/bsp ''Biosecurity & Bioterrorism: Biodefense Strategy, Practice, and Science''] * [http://www.idcostcalc.org/ Infectious Disease Cost Calculator], produced by the Center * [http://www.emergingbioleaders.org/ The Emerging Leaders in Biosecurity Initiative] * [http://www.centerforhealthsecurity.org/resources/rrc/ Rad Resilient City]; [http://www.centerforhealthsecurity.org/our-work/interactives/rad-resilient-city/index Rad Resilient City Preparedness Checklist Actions]

{{short description|parks, historic resources, reserves and recreation areas in the California State Parks system.parks, historic resources, reserves and recreation areas.}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} This is a list of parks, historic resources, reserves and recreation areas in the [[California Department of Parks and Recreation|California State Parks]] system. [[File:California-State-Parks-dots-only2.png|thumb|right|General location of California State Parks]] ==List of parks== {{clear}} {|class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%" |- ! style="width:*;" rowspan=2|'''Park name''' ! style="width:*;" rowspan=2|'''Classification''' ! style="width:*;" rowspan=2|'''County or
counties''' ! style="width:*;" colspan=2|'''Size'''{{cite journal | title = California State Park System Statistical Reports | url = http://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=23308 | publisher = California State Parks | accessdate = 2014-01-23}} ! style="width:*;" rowspan=2|'''Year established''' ! style="width:*;" class="unsortable" rowspan=2|'''Remarks''' |- !acres !ha |- || [[Admiral William Standley State Recreation Area]] | {{nowrap|State recreation area}} | [[Mendocino County, California|Mendocino]] | {{convert|45|acre|ha|disp=table|sortable=on}} |align=right| 1944 | Boasts [[Sequoia sempervirens|redwoods]] plus [[salmon]] and [[rainbow trout|steelhead]] fishing on the [[Eel River (California)|Eel River]].{{cite web | title = Admiral William Standley SRA | url = http://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=424 | publisher = California State Parks | accessdate = 2011-09-24}} |- || [[Ahjumawi Lava Springs State Park]] | State park | [[Shasta County, California|Shasta]] | {{convert|5930|acre|ha|disp=table|sortable=on}} |align=right| 1975 | Preserves a wilderness of freshwater [[spring (hydrosphere)|spring]]s and geologically recent lava flows.{{cite web | title = Ahjumawi Lava Springs SP | url = http://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=464 | publisher = California State Parks | accessdate = 2011-09-24}} |- || [[Albany State Marine Reserve]] | Park property | [[Alameda County, California|Alameda]] | | |align=right| 1985 | In development, not open to public |- || [[Anderson Marsh State Historic Park]] | State historic park | [[Lake County, California|Lake]] | {{convert|1298|acre|ha|disp=table|sortable=on}} |align=right| 1982 | Preserves a [[Schoenoplectus acutus|tule]] marsh and ancient archaeological sites of the [[Pomo people]].{{cite web | title = Anderson Marsh SHP | url = http://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=483 | publisher = California State Parks | accessdate = 2011-09-24}} |- || [[Andrew Molera State Park]] | State park | [[Monterey County, California|Monterey]] | {{convert|4766|acre|ha|disp=table|sortable=on}} |align=right| 1968 | Offers a primitive walk-in campground on the [[Big Sur]] coast.{{cite web | title = Andrew Molera SP | url = http://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=582 | publisher = California State Parks | accessdate = 2011-09-24}} |- || [[Angel Island (California)|Angel Island State Park]] | State park | [[Marin County, California|Marin]] and [[San Francisco County, California|San Francisco]] | {{convert|756|acre|ha|disp=table|sortable=on}} |align=right| 1955 | Interprets an island in [[San Francisco Bay]] whose history encompasses [[Coast Miwok]] prehistory, ranching, the 1910–1940 [[United States Immigration Station, Angel Island|Angel Island Immigration Station]], and long military use.{{cite web | title = Angel Island SP | url = http://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=468 | publisher = California State Parks | accessdate = 2011-09-24}} |- || [[Annadel State Park]] | State park | [[Sonoma County, California|Sonoma]] | {{convert|5092|acre|ha|disp=table|sortable=on}} |align=right| 1971 | Supports a variety of day-use activities at the northern end of [[Sonoma Valley]].{{cite web | title = Annadel SP | url = http://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=480 | publisher = California State Parks | accessdate = 2011-09-24}} |- || {{sort|Ano Nuevo State Park|[[Año Nuevo State Park]]}} | State park | [[San Mateo County, California|San Mateo]] | {{convert|4209|acre|ha|disp=table|sortable=on}} |align=right| 1985 | Encompasses [[Año Nuevo Island]] and Año Nuevo Point, which boasts the world's largest mainland rookery of [[northern elephant seal]]s.{{cite web | title = Año Nuevo SP | url = http://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=523 | publisher = California State Parks | accessdate = 2011-09-24}} |- || the state's most-consistent blooms of [[California poppy]], in the high [[Mojave Desert]].{{cite web | title = Antelope Valley California Poppy Reserve SNR | url = http://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=627 | publisher = California State Parks | accessdate = 2011-09-24}} |- || [[Antelope Valley Indian Museum State Historic Park]] | State historic park | [[Los Angeles County, California|Los Angeles]] | {{convert|397|acre|ha|disp=table|sortable=on}} |align=right| 1979 | Interprets the Native American cultures of the [[Great Basin]] and surrounding regions in a 1928 [[folk art]] building on the [[National Register of Historic Places|NRHP]].{{cite web | title = Antelope Valley Indian Museum SHP | url = http://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=632 | publisher = California State Parks | accessdate = 2011-09-24}} |- || [[Anza-Borrego Desert State Park]] | State park | [[San Diego County, California|San Diego]], [[Imperial County, California|Imperial]], and [[Riverside County, California|Riverside]] | {{convert|585930|acre|ha|disp=table|sortable=on}} |align=right| 1933 | Preserves a vast tract of the [[Colorado Desert]] in California's largest state park.{{cite web | title = Anza-Borrega Desert SP | url = http://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=638 | publisher = California State Parks | accessdate = 2011-09-24}} |- || [[Armstrong Redwoods State Natural Reserve]] | State natural reserve | [[Sonoma County, California|Sonoma]] | {{convert|752|acre|ha|disp=table|sortable=on}} |align=right| 1934 | Preserves a grove of [[Sequoia sempervirens|coast redwoods]].{{cite web | page.title: List of National Wild and Scenic Rivers

revision.comment: Added East Rosebud Creek in Carbon County Montana, Designated Wild and scenic by H.R. 4645, signed by the president on 8/2/18
revision.text:
[[File:WolfRiverWisconsinSept2009.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Wolf River (Fox River)|Wolf River]] in Wisconsin]] This is a list of the designated [[National Wild and Scenic River]]s in the United States. Some rivers may be listed more than once if they have designated sections in different states.
Initials of the managing agency follow the name of the river. Abbreviations used are: *USACE = [[U.S. Army Corps of Engineers]] *BLM = [[Bureau of Land Management]] *NPS = [[National Park Service]] *USFS = [[U.S. Forest Service]] *USFWS = [[U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service]]
==Alabama== *[[Sipsey Fork of the Black Warrior River|Sipsey Fork]] of the [[Black Warrior River]], USFS
==Alaska== [[File:Andreafsky River AK.jpg|thumb|right|Andreafsky River in Alaska]] [[File:Tlikakila River.jpg|thumb|right|Tlikakila River]] *[[Alagnak River]], NPS *[[Alatna River]], NPS *[[Andreafsky River]], USFWS *[[Aniakchak River]], NPS *[[Beaver Creek (Alaska)|Beaver Creek]], BLM/USFWS *[[Birch Creek (Yukon River tributary)|Birch Creek]], BLM *[[Charley River]], NPS *[[Chilikadrotna River]], NPS *[[Delta River]], BLM *[[Fortymile River]], BLM *[[Gulkana River]], BLM *[[Ivishak River]], USFWS *[[John River (Alaska)|John River]], NPS *[[Kobuk River]], NPS *[[Mulchatna River]], NPS *[[Noatak River]], NPS *[[North Fork Koyukuk River]], NPS *[[Nowitna River]], USFWS *[[Salmon River (Kobuk River)|Salmon River]], NPS *[[Selawik River]], USFWS *[[Sheenjek River]], USFWS *[[Tinayguk River]], NPS *[[Tlikakila River]], NPS *[[Unalakleet River]], BLM *[[Wind River (northern Alaska)|Wind River]], USFWS
