page.title: List of SSSIs in Mid & South Glamorgan

revision.comment: Replace [[Help:Magic_links|magic links]] with templates per [[Special:PermaLink/772743896#Future_of_magic_links|local RfC]] - [[User:PrimeBOT/13|BRFA]]
revision.text:
{{Hatnote|For data relating to SSSIs in this Area of Search see [[List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Bridgend]], [[List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Caerphilly|Caerphilly]], [[List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Cardiff|Cardiff]], [[List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Merthyr Tydfil|Merthyr Tydfil]], [[List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Rhondda Cynon Taf|Rhondda Cynon Taf]], and [[List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Vale of Glamorgan|Vale of Glamorgan]].}} [[File:Mid & South Glamorgan AOS.png|thumb|{{legend|#BF97BF|Mid & South Glamorgan AOS}}]] [[Sites of Special Scientific Interest|SSSIs]] in the UK are [[SSSI notification|notified]] using the concept of an [[Area of Search]] (AOS), an area of between {{convert|400|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} and {{convert|4000|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} in size.<ref>Joint Nature Conservation Committee (1998 revision); ''Guidelines for the Selection of Biological SSSIs'', section 4.11, p. 17. {{ISBN|1873701721}}.</ref> The Areas of Search were conceived and developed between 1975 and 1979 by the [[Nature Conservancy Council]] (NCC), based on regions created by the [[Local Government Act 1972]].<ref>Joint Nature Conservation Committee (1998 revision); ''Guidelines for the Selection of Biological SSSIs'', section 4.5, pp. 14–15. {{ISBN|1873701721}}.</ref> Whereas England had its Areas of Search based on 46 counties, those in Wales were based on a combination of the counties and smaller districts. In 1974, Wales was divided into 8 counties, with 37 [[Districts of Wales|districts]]. The NCC created 12 Welsh Areas of Search; they mostly follow county borders, but the larger counties ([[Dyfed]], [[Powys]] and [[Gwynedd]]) were divided into multiple Areas using district borders. [[Mid Glamorgan|Mid]] and [[South Glamorgan]] were merged into a single AOS, whilst [[Llanelli (district)|Llanelli district]] was included in the [[West Glamorgan]] AOS.
Due to subsequent local government reorganisation in the UK since 1972, many counties and districts have been divided, merged or renamed. Using the AOS system alone would make it difficult to search for individual SSSI citations via the [[Countryside Council for Wales]] (CCW) database without knowing 1972 region divisions. As a result, the CCW groups Welsh SSSIs using the [[Local government in Wales|subdivisions of Wales]] formed in April 1996 by the [[Local Government (Wales) Act 1994]], resulting in 22 [[Principal areas#Wales|principal areas]].
Mid & South Glamorgan AOS lies within the counties of [[Bridgend County Borough|Bridgend]], [[Caerphilly County Borough|Caerphilly]], [[Cardiff]], [[Merthyr Tydfil]], [[Rhondda Cynon Taf]] and [[Vale of Glamorgan]].
For SSSIs elsewhere in the UK, see [[List of SSSIs by Area of Search]].
==See also== *[[List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Bridgend]] *[[List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Caerphilly]] *[[List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Cardiff]] *[[List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Merthyr Tydfil]] *[[List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Rhondda Cynon Taf]] *[[List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Vale of Glamorgan]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{SSSI AOS lists}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:List of SSSIs in Mid and South Glamorgan}} [[Category:Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Mid & South Glamorgan| ]] [[Category:Lists of Sites of Special Scientific Interest by Area of Search|Mid and South Glamorgan]]

page.title: List of animals that produce silk

revision.comment: /* Other animals */Typo
revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=December 2014}} [[Silk]] is produced by a variety of animals, for different purposes, with various types being produced.
==Insects== *[[Silkworm]]s produce silk when undergoing larval to adult metamorphosis. *[[Raspy cricket]]s produce silk to form nests. *[[Honeybee]] and [[bumblebee]] larvae produce silk to strengthen the wax cells in which they pupate.<ref name="sciencedaily2007">{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2007/11/071126092140.htm |title=Bees Are The New Silkworms |publisher=ScienceDaily |date= |accessdate=2014-06-06}}</ref> *[[Bulldog ants]] spin cocoons to protect themselves during pupation.<ref name="sciencedaily2007"/> *[[Weaver ants]] use silk to connect leaves together to make communal nests.<ref name="sciencedaily2007"/> *[[Embioptera|Webspinners]] have silk glands on their front legs. *[[Hornet]]s *[[Silverfish]] *[[Mayflies]] *[[Thrips]] *[[Leafhoppers]] produce silk nests under the leaves of the trees where they live, to protect them against predators.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1440-6055.2011.00813.x/abstract |title=Silk production by the Australian endemic leafhopper Kahaono montana Evans (Cicadellidae: Typhlocybinae: Dikraneurini) provides protection from predators |date= |accessdate=2014-07-09 |doi=10.1111/j.1440-6055.2011.00813.x |journal=Australian Journal of Entomology}}</ref> *[[Beetles]] *[[Lacewings]] *[[Fleas]] *[[Flies]] *[[Midges]]
==Other animals== *The family [[Projapygidae]] in the order [[Diplura]] have [[Cercus|cerci]] that contain silk glands.<ref>[http://www.ento.csiro.au/education/hexapods/diplura.html Diplura]</ref> *The mussel ''[[Pinna nobilis]]'' creates silk to bond itself to rocks. It is used to make [[sea silk]]. *[[Spiders]] make [[spider silk]] for various purposes such as weaving their webs, protecting their eggs or as a safety line. *The crustacean [[Peramphithoe femorata]] use silk to make a nest out of kelp blades. *[[Carp]] produce [[fibroin|fibroin units]], a component of silk, to attach their eggs to rocks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mapoflife.org/topics/topic_267_Silk-production-and-use-in-arthropods/ |title=Silk production and use in arthropods |publisher=Map of Life |date= |accessdate=2014-06-06}}</ref> *[[Spider mite]]s make webs that protects them against predators. *[[Goats]] have been genetically modified to produce milk containing extractable silk proteins.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Elices, M.; Guinea, G. V.; Plaza, G. R.; Karatzas, C.; Riekel, C.; Agulló-Rueda, F.; Daza, R.; Pérez-Rigueiro, J. |year= 2011 |title= Bioinspired Fibers Follow the Track of Natural Spider Silk |journal= Macromolecules |volume= 44 |pages= 1166–1176 |doi= 10.1021/ma102291m|bibcode = 2011MaMol..44.1166E |issue=5 |last2= Guinea |last3= Plaza |last4= Karatzas |last5= Riekel |last6= Agulló-Rueda |last7= Daza |last8= Pérez-Rigueiro }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2658764/ US National Library of Medicine, National Institutes of Health, documentation about various animals that produce silk and why.]
[[Category:Biology-related lists|Animals]] [[Category:Silk]] [[Category:Lists of animals|silk]]

2016b</small> (Candidate division WWE3 bacterial) * "Lindowbacteria" <small>Anantharaman et al. 2016</small> * "Margulisbacteria" <small>Anantharaman et al. 2016</small> * Modulibacteria (Candidate phylum KSB3) * "Nitrospinae" <small>Lucker et al. 2013</small> * "Raymondbacteria" <small>Anantharaman et al. 2016</small> * "Riflebacteria" <small>Anantharaman et al. 2016</small> * "Rokubacteria" <small>Hug et al. 2016</small> * "Schekmanbacteria" <small>Anantharaman et al. 2016</small> * Dependentiae <small>Yeoh et al. 2016</small> (Candidate phylum TM6) * "Wallbacteria" <small>Anantharaman et al. 2016</small> * "Wirthbacteria" <small>Hug et al. 2016</small>

page.title: List of conventional hydroelectric power stations

revision.comment: cite tool made an error
revision.text:
This article lists [[hydroelectricity|hydroelectric]] [[power station]]s that generate power using the [[Hydroelectricity#Generating methods|conventional]] [[dam]]med method. This list includes power stations that are larger than {{nowrap|1,000 [[Megawatt|MW]]}} in maximum net capacity, and are operational or under construction. Those power stations that are smaller than {{nowrap|1,000 MW}}, or those that are only at a planning/proposal stage may be found in regional lists, listed at the end of the page. As of 2016, the largest hydroelectric power station is the [[Three Gorges Dam]] in [[List of power stations in China|China]], rated at {{nowrap|22,500 MW}} in total installed capacity. After passing on 7 December 2007 the {{nowrap|14,000 MW}} mark of the [[Itaipu Dam]], the facility was ranked as the [[List of largest power stations in the world|largest power-generating facility]] ever built. The dam is {{convert|181|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} high, {{convert|2335|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|115|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} in width. Power is generated by 32 [[water turbine|turbines]] rated at {{nowrap|700 MW}}, and two turbines rated {{nowrap|50 MW}}, which are used to power the facility itself. Construction of this dam commenced in 1994, and was completed in 2012, nearly two decades after it started. The next four largest dams after the Three Gorges Dam are the Itaipu Dam, [[Xiluodu Dam]], [[Guri Dam]] and the [[Tucurui Dam]], rated at {{nowrap|14,000 MW}}, {{nowrap|13,860 MW}}, {{nowrap|10,235 MW}} and {{nowrap|8,370 MW}} respectively. All five dams are the largest power-generating bodies respectively, before the [[Kashiwazaki-Kariwa Nuclear Power Plant]] at {{nowrap|8,212 MW}}, the largest [[Non-renewable resource|non-renewable]] energy-generating facility in the world. The currently planned [[Grand Inga Dam]] would be nearly twice the size of the Three Gorges Dam at {{nowrap|39,000 MW}}, surpassing all power-generating facilities once it passes the current-highest {{nowrap|22,500 MW}} mark. ==Hydroelectric power stations== The following two lists rank the 186 largest conventional hydroelectric power stations that have an installed electric power generation capacity of at least 1,000 [[Watt#Megawatt|MW]] and also 31 plants under construction with planned capacity of at least 1,000 [[Watt#Megawatt|MW]]. [[File:Dreischluchtendamm hauptwall 2006.jpg|alt=Aerial view of a huge concrete structure located between the mountains, with buildings, power lines and construction and lifting cranes|thumb|200px|The [[Three Gorges Dam]], the largest power-generating facility in the world]] [[File:Itaipu 195.jpg|alt=Aerial view of a huge concrete structure located between some low hills and a river, with some large pipes at the base and power lines at the top of the structure and a road|thumb|200px|The [[Itaipu Dam]]]] [[File:Guri Dam in Venezuela.JPG|alt=Ground-level view of a large concrete structure in the left, power lines at the top and a parking lot with many cars in it|thumb|200px|The [[Guri Dam]]]] [[File:Usina de Tucuruí.jpg|alt=Aerial view of a concrete structure, a low hill and massive amounts of water that spur in a waterfall like way from the structure|thumb|200px|The [[Tucurui Dam]]]] [[File:Grand Coulee Dam Panorama Smaller.jpg|alt=Image of some mountains, a large structure, a river and a village near the river|thumb|200px|The [[Grand Coulee Dam]]]] [[File:Кран для гидротехнического строительства.jpg|thumb|alt=Image of a large water retaining structure that spills water like a waterfall, some power lines and a construction crane|200px|The [[Krasnoyarsk Hydroelectric Dam]]]] [[File:Caruachi Dam in Venezuela.JPG|alt=Image of a wall like structure in left, a raging river in the right and power lines located on low hills|thumb|200px|The [[Caruachi Dam]]]] [[File:Hoovernewbridge.jpg|alt=Aerial view of a white structure located between mountains with a lake, roads in the left, power lines in the right and a pylon with some wires in the low part|thumb|200px|The [[Hoover Dam]]]] [[File:Srisailam-dam-with-gates-open-2.jpg|alt=Aerial image of a river flowing from a concrete structure in the shape of an waterfall, with some forest in the background|thumb|200px|The [[Srisailam Dam]]]] [[File:Sardar Sarovar Dam 2006, India.jpg|alt=Image of a wall like structure located between mountains with curves at the bottom of it, some kind of plant and a rusty rail bar|thumb|200px|The [[Narmada Dam]]]] [[File:KebanDam.JPG|thumb|alt=Aerial view of a concrete structure located between mountains that has a long ridge, a road and large pipes and an electric power transformation station|200px|The [[Keban Dam]]]] [[File:IJzeren Poort Stuwdam.JPG|thumb|200px|right|[[Iron Gate (Danube)|Iron Gates Dam]], [[Romania]]-[[Serbia]]]] [[File:Évacuateur de crues R-B.jpg|thumb|alt=A giant staircase carved in the rock|200px|The [[Robert-Bourassa generating station|Robert-Bourassa]] and [[Robert-Bourassa generating station|La Grande-2-A]] generating stations common spillway.]] [[File:Akosombo Dam.jpg|alt=Aerial view of a large rock structure located in a forest between the mountains, large pipes and a cloudy sky|thumb|200px|The [[Akosombo Dam]]]] [[File:PA I II III.jpg|alt=Aerial image of a coastal mountainous place with some structures located on top of it and some power lines|thumb|200px|The [[Paulo Afonso Hydroelectric Complex]]]] [[File:AswanHighDam Egypt.jpg|alt=Image of Aswan High Dam, looking east, with powerhouse in background|thumb|200px|The [[Aswan High Dam]]]] [[File:Ataturk dam 1-GAP.jpg|alt=Aerial view of a large structure located between mountains and a large lake|thumb|200px|The [[Atatürk Dam]]]] page.title: List of nature centers in North Carolina

revision.comment: Updated listings
revision.text:
<!-- Note: Please do not add websites for nature centers with existing Wikipedia articles. All websites should be listed on the main article. -->
This is a list of [[nature center]]s and environmental education centers in the state of [[North Carolina]].
To use the sortable tables: click on the icons at the top of each column to sort that column in alphabetical order; click again for reverse alphabetical order.
{{See also|List of nature centers in the United States}}
{| class="wikitable sortable" ! Name ! Location ! County ! Region ! Summary |- | Agapé Center for Environmental Education || [[Fuquay-Varina, North Carolina|Fuquay-Varina]] || [[Wake County, North Carolina|Wake]] || [[Research Triangle|Triangle]] || [http://www.agapecenterforee.org website], 624 acres, experiential learning about the environment for groups |- | [[Airlie Gardens]] || [[Wilmington, North Carolina|Wilmington]] || [[New Hanover County, North Carolina|New Hanover]] || [[Eastern North Carolina|Eastern]] || 67 acres, formal gardens with environmental education programs for youth and adults |- | [[Alligator River National Wildlife Refuge]] || [[Manteo, North Carolina|Manteo]] || [[Dare County, North Carolina|Dare]] || Eastern || Visitor center with exhibits about the ecosystem of the refuge, conservation, education programs |- | Annie Louise Wilkerson Nature Preserve || [[Raleigh, North Carolina|Raleigh]] || Wake || Triangle || [http://www.raleighnc.gov/arts/content/PRecRecreation/Articles/AnnieLWilkersonNaturePreservePark.html website], 156 acres, operated by the City |- | [[Bald Head Island Conservancy]] || [[Bald Head Island, North Carolina|Bald Head Island]] || [[Brunswick County, North Carolina|Brunswick]] || Eastern || Family adventure programs, summer camps, nature tours, turtle walks |- | Balsam Mountain Preserve || [[Sylva, North Carolina|Sylva]] || [[Jackson County, North Carolina|Jackson]] || || [http://www.bmtrust.org/ website], operated by the Balsam Mountain Trust, about 4,400 acres, nature center includes live animals, general public must have confirmed reservations to visit |- | Bass Lake Park || [[Holly Springs, North Carolina|Holly Springs]] || Wake || Triangle || [http://www.hollyspringsnc.us/index.aspx?NID=320 website], park features 100-acre lake stocked for fishing, nature center with native animal exhibits, operated by the City |- | Betsy-Jeff Penn 4-H Educational Center || [[Reidsville, North Carolina|Reidsville]] || [[Rockingham County, North Carolina|Rockingham]] || || [http://www.bjpenn4h.org/ website], almost 200 acres, research based educational experiences for schools and groups, summer camp |- | Blue Jay Point County Park || [[Raleigh, North Carolina|Raleigh]] || Wake || Triangle || [http://www.wakegov.com/parks/bluejay/Pages/default.aspx website], 236 acres, operated by the County |- | Blue Planet Water Environmental Center || [[Huntersville, North Carolina|Huntersville]] || [[Mecklenburg County, North Carolina|Mecklenburg]] || [[Charlotte metropolitan area|Charlotte area]] || [http://charmeck.org/city/charlotte/Utilities/BluePlanet/Pages/home.aspx website], hands-on educational center about water and wastewater, operated by Charlotte-Mecklenburg Utilities |- | [[Carolina Beach State Park]] || [[Carolina Beach, North Carolina|Carolina Beach]] || New Hanover || Eastern || 761 acres, visitor center exhibits about the park's carnivorous plants |- | [[Carolina Raptor Center]] || [[Charlotte, North Carolina|Charlotte]] || Mecklenburg || Charlotte area || [http://www.carolinaraptorcenter.org website], raptor rehabilitation center with exhibits |- | Centennial Campus Center for Wildlife Education || [[Raleigh, North Carolina|Raleigh]] || Wake || Triangle || [http://www.ncwildlife.org/Learning/EducationCenters/Centennial.aspx website], headquarters of the [[North Carolina Wildlife Resources Commission]], features wetland exhibits and overlook, exhibits about wildlife conservation in North Carolina |- | Clark Park Nature Center || [[Fayetteville, North Carolina|Fayetteville]] || [[Cumberland County, North Carolina|Cumberland]] || Eastern || [http://www.fcpr.us/outdoor_programs/clark_park.aspx website], 72 acres, operated by the City |- | [[Clemmons Educational State Forest]] || [[Clayton, North Carolina|Clayton]] || [[Johnston County, North Carolina|Johnston]] || Eastern || Features Forestry Exhibit Center with interactive exhibits about the ecology of forests, soil, water, wildlife and the state's cultural history |- | Cool Springs Environmental Education Center || [[New Bern, North Carolina|New Bern]] || [[Craven County, North Carolina|Craven]] || || [http://www.weyerhaeuser.com/sustainability/communities/stakeholder-engagement/cool-springs/ website], 1,700 acres of forestland along the [[Neuse River]], programs on forests and [[forestry]], operated by [[Weyerhaeuser]], requires appointment |- | Crowder District Park || [[Apex, North Carolina|Apex]] || Wake || Triangle || [http://www.wakegov.com/parks/crowder/Pages/default.aspx website], 33 acres, operated by the County |- | Dan Nicholas Park || [[Salisbury, North Carolina|Salisbury]] || [[Rowan County, North Carolina|Rowan]] || Charlotte area || [http://www.dannicholas.net website], operated by the County, park with wildlife, nature center, carousel, water park, small farm with animals, other family attractions |- | [[Discovery Place Nature]] || Charlotte || Mecklenburg || Charlotte area || Interactive nature exhibits and live animal displays of the [[Piedmont (United States)|Piedmont region]], adjacent to 98-acre [[Freedom Park (Charlotte, North Carolina)|Freedom Park]], operated by [[Discovery Place]] |- | Foothills Equestrian Nature Center || [[Tryon, North Carolina|Tryon]] ||[[Polk County, North Carolina|Polk]] || [[Western North Carolina|Western]] || revision.text:
This is a partial listing of '''tributaries of the Fraser River'''. [[Tributary|Tributaries]] and sub-tributaries are hierarchically listed in upstream order from the mouth of the [[Fraser River]]. The list may also include streams known as creeks and sloughs. Lakes are noted in italics.
All of these streams are in [[British Columbia]], Canada, except the upper [[Vedder River]] (Chilliwack River) and some of its tributaries, which are in [[Washington (state)|Washington]], United States.

revision.comment: Rescuing 3 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.1)
revision.text:
'''Little River''' may refer to ten streams by that name in the U.S. state of North Carolina:
*[[Little River (Albemarle Sound)]], a tributary of [[Albemarle Sound]] forming a portion of the border between [[Pasquotank County, North Carolina|Pasquotank]] and [[Perquimans County, North Carolina|Perquimans]] counties. *[[Little River (Cape Fear River)]], a tributary of the [[Cape Fear River]] rising in [[Moore County, North Carolina|Moore County]]. This river forms a portion of the boundary between Moore and [[Hoke County, North Carolina|Hoke]] counties and between [[Cumberland County, North Carolina|Cumberland]] and [[Harnett County, North Carolina|Harnett]] counties. *[[Little River (Eno River)]], a tributary of the [[Eno River]] rising in [[Orange County, North Carolina|Orange County]] and entering the Eno River in [[Durham County, North Carolina|Durham County]]. *[[Little River (French Broad River)]], a tributary of the [[French Broad River]] in [[Transylvania County, North Carolina|Transylvania County]]. *[[Little River (Horry County, South Carolina)]], a river in South Carolina that grazes the North Carolina border before entering the Atlantic Ocean in South Carolina. *[[Little River (Jacob Fork)]], a tributary of the Jacob Fork of the [[Catawba River]] in [[Burke County, North Carolina|Burke County]]. *[[Little River (Neuse River)]], a tributary of the Neuse River *[[Little River (North Carolina-Virginia)]], a tributary of the [[New River (Kanawha River)|New River]] rising in [[Alleghany County, North Carolina]] and flowing through [[Grayson County, Virginia]]. Note: The New River has another, larger tributary further downstream in Virginia also called [[Little River (New River)]]. *[[Little River (Pee Dee River)]], a tributary of the [[Pee Dee River]] that flows through [[Randolph County, North Carolina|Randolph]], [[Montgomery County, North Carolina|Montgomery]], and [[Richmond County, North Carolina|Richmond]] counties. *[[Little River (Roanoke River)]], a former tributary of the [[Roanoke River]], now submerged by [[Lake Gaston]].
==References== *https://web.archive.org/web/20070516123853/http://www.bae.ncsu.edu/programs/extension/wqg/neuse/maps.html *http://www.neuseriver.org *https://web.archive.org/web/20070416010555/http://www.newsobserver.com/928/story/442544.html *https://web.archive.org/web/20070408004554/http://enoriver.org/eno/River/about.html *http://geonames.usgs.gov/pls/gnispublic USGS GNIS
{{SIA|rivers}}

revision.comment: Minor comma grammar. Also, it doesn't really matter, but caesium should probably be linked the same way both times - "Caesium" is preferred in scientific papers (and on Wikipedia) per the IUPAC standard.
revision.text:
'''Margaritasite''' is a yellow, [[caesium]]-bearing [[mineral]] in the [[carnotite]] group. Its [[chemical formula]] is ([[caesium|Cs]], [[potassium|K]], [[hydronium|H<sub>3</sub>O]])<sub>2</sub>([[uranium|U]][[oxygen|O]]<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>[[vanadium|V]]<sub>2</sub>O<sub>8</sub>'''·'''[[water|H<sub>2</sub>O]] and its [[crystal system]] is [[monoclinic]].
==Name and discovery== It was first described in 1982 from the Margaritas [[uranium]] deposit in the [[Peña Blanca, Chihuahua|Peña Blanca]] district of the municipality of [[Aldama, Chihuahua|Aldama]], in the [[Mexico|Mexican]] [[Mexican state|state]] of [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]].
==See also== * [[List of minerals]]
==References== * [http://www.mindat.org/min-2572.html Mindat.org - Margaritasite] * [http://www.handbookofmineralogy.com/pdfs/margaritasite.pdf Handbook of Mineralogy - Margaritasite]
[[Category:Vanadate minerals]] [[Category:Caesium minerals]] [[Category:Potassium minerals]] [[Category:Uranium minerals]] [[Category:Monoclinic minerals]]
{{oxide-mineral-stub}}

page.title: Mount Cameroon and Bioko montane forests

revision.comment: /* Conservation and threats */
revision.text:
The '''Mount Cameroon and Bioko montane forests''' [[ecoregion]], of the [[tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forests]] [[Biome]], are in [[Afromontane]] habitats in [[Cameroon]] and [[Equatorial Guinea]] of Africa.
== Setting == The ecoregion includes the distinct [[montane forest]]s on the higher elevations of two [[volcano|volcanic]] peaks, [[Mount Cameroon]], which lies in Cameroon near the coast, and [[Bioko]], a volcanic island to the southwest in [[Equatorial Guinea]].
Both Bioko and Mount Cameroon are part of the [[Cameroon Volcanic Line]], a line of volcanoes that runs northeast-southwest across the [[Cameroon Highlands]] and extending into the [[Atlantic Ocean]] as the islands of Bioko, [[São Tomé]], [[Príncipe]], and [[Annobon]]. At over 4,000m Mount Cameroon is the highest peak in west Africa, and is still an active volcano. The southwestern slopes of these mountains have a wet climate all-year round.
== Flora == The montane forests of Mount Cameroon and Bioko are home to the distinct [[Afromontane]] flora of Africa's high mountains. The chief plant communities are montane forests, montane grasslands, and heathlands. At least 42 plant species are strictly endemic and another 50 near-endemic to Mount Cameroon.
== Fauna == 370 species of birds have been recorded on Mount Cameroon, including some endemics. There is less variety of mammals, and most larger mammals have disappeared, but there are some endemics such as the Cameroon soft-furred mouse ([[Praomys morio]]), and a greater variety of reptiles and amphibians including the endemic toad, [[Werneria preussi]].
== Conservation and threats == The forest of Mount Cameroon is threatened, especially at lower elevations, by conversion to agriculture and timber production, and are mostly unprotected. On Bioko Bioko some habitat is protected by [[Luba Crater Scientific Reserve]].
== See also == * [[Lower Guinean forests]]
== References and external links == * {{WWF ecoregion|name=Mount Cameroon and Bioko montane forests|id=at0121}} * {{NatGeo ecoregion|id=at0121|name=Mount Cameroon and Bioko montane forests}} * [http://www.birdlife.org/datazone/ebas/index.html?action=EbaHTMDetails.asp&sid=81&m=0 Cameroon mountains Endemic Bird Area (BirdLife International)]
{{coord missing|Cameroon}}
{{-}}

revision.comment: trim
revision.text:
[[File:Emblem of the Norwegian Polar Institute.svg|thumb|Emblem]][[Image:Polarmiljosenteret.jpg|thumb|The Norwegian Polar Institute's office building in Tromsø]] The '''Norwegian Polar Institute''' ([[Norwegian language|Norwegian]]: '''Norsk Polarinstitutt''') is [[Norway]]'s central governmental institution for scientific research, mapping and environmental monitoring in the Arctic and the Antarctic. It is run under the auspices of the Norwegian Ministry of Climate and Environment. The institute conducts research in the polar regions, provides management relevant knowledge for the Norwegian authorities, and organizes expeditions to the [[Arctic]] and [[Antarctic]] regions. The institute runs year-round the [http://www.npolar.no/en/about-us/stations-vessels/sverdrup/ Sverdrup research station] in [[Ny-Ålesund]] on Svalbard and the [http://www.npolar.no/en/about-us/stations-vessels/troll/ Troll station] in [[Antarctica]]. In addition the [http://www.npolar.no/en/about-us/stations-vessels/norvegia/ Norvegia station] which is located on the [[Bouvet Island]] in the Southern Ocean and the [http://www.npolar.no/en/about-us/stations-vessels/tor/ Tor Field Station] on Antarctica are used for shorter term work. Its offices are in [[Tromsø]] and [[Longyearbyen]], [[Svalbard]], in addition to the research stations in [[Queen Maud Land]] and Svalbard, and employs approximately 150 persons. It has the responsibility to enforce international treaties regarding Antarctic activities by Norwegian citizens or corporations.
The institute was founded as ''Norges Svalbard- og Ishavsundersøkelser'' by [[Adolf Hoel|AdolfAdo Hoel]] in 1928.
== Staff== === Directors ===
*1948 - 1957 [[Harald Sverdrup (oceanographer)|Harald Ulrik Sverdrup]] *1957 - 1960 [[Anders K. Orvin]] *1960 - 1983 [[Tore Gjelsvik]] *1983 - 1991 [[Odd Rogne]] *1991 - 1993 [[Nils Are Øritsland]] *1993 - 2005 [[Olav Orheim]] *2005 - 2017 [[Jan-Gunnar Winther]] *2017 - [[Ole Arve Misund]] == Greenhouse gases research == {{Main|Greenhouse gas}}
Atmospheric levels of the main greenhouse gas have set another new peak in a sign of the industrial rise of Asian economies led by [[China]]. The Norwegian Polar Institute has stated that in 2008 "the levels already in January are higher than 2007" .<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.planetark.com/dailynewsstory.cfm/newsid/46517/story.htm |title=Greenhouse Gases at New Peak in Sign of Asia Growth |last1=Doyle |first1=Alister |date=January 21, 2008 |website=planetark.com |publisher= |access-date=August 10, 2016 |quote=}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
==Ex== [[Category:Education and research in Tromsø]] [[Category:Research institutes in Norway]] [[Category:Government agencies of Norway|Polar Institute]] [[Category:Geoscience institutes]] [[Category:Arctic research]] [[Category:Science and technology in Svalbard]] [[Category:Norway and the Antarctic]] [[Category:Ministry of Climate and the Environment (Norway)]] [[Category:1928 establishments in Norway]] [[Category:Antarctic research]]

revision.text:
{{Use Pakistani English|date=June 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox person |name = Omer Tarin (also Omar Tarin and Omer Tareen) | image = Omer khan tarin 2015.jpg |birth_name = Omer Salim Khan |birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1967|3|10}} |birth_place = [[Peshawar]], Pakistan |citizenship = Pakistani |occupation = Poet, writer, scholar, [[Qadiriyya]]-[[Chishti Order|Chishtiyya-Nizamiyya]] [[sufi]]<ref>According to Tarin he also trained with the [[Mevlevi Order|Mevlevi Sufi Order]], the [[Naqshbandi]]s and also in the [[Rinzai school]] of [[Zen]] [[Buddhism]] during the 1990s. See recent interview by Salma Rafiq, in 'Brilliant Writings' magazine, Lahore, Pakistan, December 2014</ref> |years_active = }} '''Omer Tarin''' (real name: Omer Salim Khan),<ref>Apart from his pen-name, he is also known within Sufi contexts as 'Omer Nizami' or 'Omer Chishti-Nizami'</ref> [[Royal Asiatic Society|FRAS]], [[Fellow|FRPA]], etc.; born 10 March 1967<ref>[https://www.birthdaycelebs.com/omer-tarin/ Astrological notes on celebrities: Omer Tarin]</ref> , is a Pakistani [[poet]], research scholar, [[Social activists|social activist]] and [[mysticism|mystic]].<ref>[https://sufichishtorg.weebly.com/ Site of the Ishq-Nuri Chishti-Nizami Tariqa of Pakistan, listing its main spiritual lineage] Retrieved 28 November 2015</ref> In some editions of his works, the name is written as '''Omar Tarin'''.
==Background== Tarin was born in [[Peshawar]] city, in 1967 to the Tarin (or [[Tareen]]) family, or clan, of [[Talokar (village)]],<ref>[http://www.woking.gov.uk/woking/heritage/muslimburialground/sikandarkhan Note on Sepoy Sikandar Khan and Tarin family of Talokar, NWFP, Pakistan, including mention of Omer Salim Khan/Omer Tarin] Retrieved Woking Borough Council site, UK December 2015</ref> of the [[Hazara, Pakistan|Hazara]] region of the North-West Frontier (now [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]]), while his father was posted as a senior civil servant and administrator in Peshawar.<ref>Biographical information in the Introduction to "A Sad Piper", Leo Books, [[Islamabad]], 1994 edition {{ISBN|969-8127-03-8}}; and 2nd edition London, UK, 1995, p. vi</ref> From his maternal side, he is related to the Hayat family of [[Wah]], as well as the [[Hakim Ahmad Shuja|Hakim Khana family]] of [[Lahore]], [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ilyask2.wordpress.com/tag/omer-tarin/ |title=Omer Tarin " ilyask2 |publisher=Ilyask2.wordpress.com |date=28 November 2011 |accessdate=19 November 2012}}</ref><ref>Thus, from his paternal side he is a great-grandson of Khan sahib [[Abdul Majid Khan Tarin]], OBE, and from his maternal side a great-grandson of [[Sir Sikandar Hayat Khan]] and famed writer [[Hakim Ahmad Shuja]]. See Ilyas K, Interview of Nov 2011 above</ref> He was educated at the [[Burn Hall School]] (now [[Army Burn Hall College]]), [[Abbottabad]] and the [[Aitchison College]], Pakistan, prior to graduating from the [[University of the Punjab]], Lahore.<ref>Luminita Karim, article on Omer Tarin in Weekly Poetry Review, in "The Muslim" daily, Islamabad, 28 October 1994, p. 18</ref> He later obtained various higher degrees in English and [[Post-colonial]] Studies from Pakistan and abroad.<ref>Introduction, 'A Sad Piper', 1994</ref>
==Career== After a short time in the civil service of Pakistan, Tarin resigned to become a full-time university lecturer and research scholar and involved himself in literary and academic pursuits.<ref>'Brilliant writings' magazine interview, December 2014 issue</ref> He has published five volumes of poetry in English so far, widely reviewed in Pakistan and abroad, as well as several poems published in [[anthologies]] and collections worldwide.<ref>'Brilliant writings' Dec 2014</ref><ref>[http://museindia.com/Home/PastIssue Omer Tarin, a Sufic poem in Muse India No 73, May–June 2017]</ref> His volumes of poetry are : ''A Sad Piper'' (1994; 1996 UK),<ref>[http://explore.bl.uk/primo_library/libweb/action/display.do?tabs=moreTab&ct=display&fn=search&doc=BLL01007466238&indx=1&recIds=BLL01007466238&recI British Library Catalog entry retrieved April 2016]</ref>''The Anvil of Dreams'' (1995),<ref>[https://www.worldcat.org/title/anvil-of-dreams-poems/oclc/44392627&referer=brief_results WORLDCAT catalog entry retrieved April 2016]</ref> ''Burnt Offerings'' (1996, 1997) and ''Riverbeds Flowing''<ref>{{cite web|author=Mahmood A. Khwaja|title=Book Review, "The Poet as Spiritual Being: A Review of Omer Tarin's Burnt Offerings"|publisher=''Sangat'' literary journal, Vol. 27, No. 3, |date=Autumn 1999|pages=21–24|url=http://ilyask2.wordpress.com/2011/11/27/book-review-omer-tarin-1999/|accessdate=19 November 2012}}</ref> and ''The Harvest of Love Songs'' (1997, 2000; and UK ed 2003). Since 2005, he has not published any new volumes of poetry although he has been publishing poems independently from time to time.<ref>He has, however, recently brought out a small volume of prose writings, "Selected Shorter Essays", 2011. {{ISBN|978-1-105-15532-1}}; as well as a collection of short stories, "From Hill and Plain" {{ISBN|978-1-105-18623-3}}, as well as some other prose works</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://openlibrary.org/authors/OL101176A/Omar_Tarin |title=Omar Tarin |publisher=Open Library |date= |accessdate=19 November 2012}}</ref><ref>[http://www.poetsanddreamers.com/poetry 2016 poetry showcase 'Poets and Dreamers' magazine, USA]</ref> In recent years, he has also been involved in various literary and historical projects of an academic nature, chiefly focussing on the colonial history of South Asia,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jullundurassociation.org/ |title=News |publisher=Jullundurassociation.org |date= |accessdate=19 November 2012}}</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=EXXGBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA523&lpg=PA523&dq=%27%27Omer+Tarin%27%2 Notes of Peter Oborne's book 'Wounded Tiger' (2014), referring to Omer Tarin] Retrieved December 2015</ref> in particular North-Western Pakistan. Recent academic publications include works on [[military history]]/[[military campaign|campaigns]] on the Frontier<ref>For example, see the Acknowledgements to Tarin in Stuart Flinders' book ''Cult of a Dark Hero: John Nicholson of Delhi'', pub: London, IB Tauris & Co, 2018. {{ISBN|9781788312363}}, p.xix</ref> and some work on [[Rudyard Kipling]] and Kipling's [[India]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.johnradcliffe.pwp.blueyonder.co.uk/textfiles/KJ327.txt |title=The Kipling Society |publisher=Johnradcliffe.pwp.blueyonder.co.uk |accessdate=19 November 2012}}</ref> A number of these works are available or referenced online, and were published in the ''Kipling Journal'',<ref>For example, in Vol 84, No 339, December 2010, pp. 35–52; and Vol 82, No 327, June 2008, pp. 10–22</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kipling.org.uk/all_name.htm |title=Name Index |publisher=Kipling.org.uk |date= |accessdate=19 November 2012}}</ref> UK and the ''Journal of the Indian Military Historical Society'', also the UK. He has diverse academic and literary interests and is a Fellow of the [[Royal Asiatic Society]], UK, [[The Tolkien Society]] (UK), associate of the [[Kipling Society]], and the former [[Indian Military Historical Society]] (IMHS).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imhs.org.uk/ |title=Indian Military Historical Society |publisher=Imhs.org.uk |date= |accessdate=19 November 2012}}</ref>
In addition to his literary and academic interests, Omer Tarin has also long been involved in occasional social activism, especially in relation to environmental, [[forests]] and [[wildlife]] [[Conservation (ethic)|conservation]], in the [[Hazara, Pakistan]] area.<ref>'Brilliant writings' Dec 2014</ref> He also makes comments on various aspects of global politics and environmental issues in the media, from time to time.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/8025574.stm |title=Americas | World reaction to Obama's 100 days |publisher=BBC News |date=29 April 2009 |accessdate=18 November 2012}}</ref><ref>[http://combustus.com/postcard-from-pakistan-cross-cultural-friendships-drown-out-the-silencing/ Interview from 'Combustus' online literary and art magazine, Oregon, USA, September 2013] Retrieved 18 November 2018</ref> He also ran a research and higher education institute in Northern Pakistan from 2003 to 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prachyareview.com/two-poems-by-omer-tarin/ |title= Introductory note to Omer Tarin's poems in Prachya Review, Bangladesh, September 2015}}</ref><ref>See 'The News' international daily, Omer Tarin's Literary comments/Book review The News International, Islamabad, Pakistan ed 27 June 2010</ref> [[File:Hill tracts and forest near Abbottabad.jpg|thumb|Hazara hills and forests near Abbottabad]] In addition, he had also in the past established a private library for research students and scholars in a wing of his home<ref>Which closed down in 2016, with the bulk of material going to several public libraries and archives in Pakistan. See Google Review below</ref> and also donated a sizable collection to the [[National Archives of Pakistan]] and the [[University of Azad Jammu and Kashmir]].<ref>[https://plus.google.com/113726032474375906986/about Google Review about the Omer Salim Khan Private Library Pakistan] December 2015</ref>
Since 2003, Tarin has mostly been managing his properties in several parts of Pakistan.<ref>See Interview by Salma Rafiq 2014, as above</ref>
==Poetry== Omer Tarin's poetry holds a notable place in Pakistani poetry in English.<ref>Pilkington, Introduction to 2nd ed 'A Sad Piper', 1996 {{ISBN|1-86033-185-8}}</ref> It has a certain erudite grace, a universal, humanitarian quality and passionate involvement that raises it above the general run of much of the work recently published in Pakistan and South Asia, generally.<ref>[[Mazhar ul Islam]], Preface to 'Harvest Season', Islamabad, 1997 {{ISBN|969-8127-11-9}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://ginamc.blogspot.com/2014/12/omer-tarin-poet-writer.html |title=Gina's Interview Series: Famous People From Around the World |publisher=Gmcknight.com |date= |accessdate=19 November 2012}}</ref> It seems to be deeply influenced by the [[Mysticism|mystic]], [[Transcendence (religion)|transcendental]] tradition of the great [[Sufi]] and [[Bhakti]] poets of the [[South Asian subcontinent]],<ref>Ayesha Sadozai. ''Safar-Namah by Omer Tarin: A Critical Note'', in Ellipsis literary magazine, Vermont, USA 2013.p 18</ref> such as Hazrat [[Baba Farid]] 'Ganj Shakar',<ref>ul Salam, 1997, aa</ref> Baba [[Bulleh Shah]], [[Amir Khusrow]], [[Rahman Baba]], [[Kabir Das]] and even [[Guru Nanak]],<ref>ul Islam, 1997, aa</ref> in addition to that of the classical Sufi poets and writers of [[Islam]] such as [[Rumi]], [[Hafiz Shirazi|Hafiz]], [[Saadi (poet)|Saadi]] and [[Attar of Nishapur|Attar]]<ref>ul Islam, 1997, aa</ref><ref>[http://www.museindia.com/Home/ViewContentData] Article by Sufi Tarin on Hazrat Syed [[Meher Ali Shah]], a Punjabi Sufi poet, in [[Muse India]], No 73, May–June 2017, Special Feature on Sufism and Sufi Literature</ref> —in terms of its essential [[Imagination|lyricism]], its engagement with 'human' issues, problems and challenges; as well as in the experimentation with form and content, in ways that have certainly not been attempted by other poets here today.<ref>{{cite web|author=Ahmad Zafar|title=''Frontier Post''|date=12 May 1995|page=15|url= http://www.thefrontierpost.com|accessdate=19 November 2012}}</ref> He has also a fascination with [[Japan]] and [[Japanese Culture]] and [[esoteric]], or [[meditative]] practices, which find reflection in his works.<ref>For a detailed report on Haiku and Omer Tarin's work, please see Yasuhiko Shigemoto's interview in ''The [[Mainichi]] shimbun'', Japan, issue of 15 August 1998; present Japanese website http://mainichi.jp</ref> In the words of [[Tariq Rahman]], a noted Pakistani scholar and literary critic, "a certain force of vitality" and creative 'intensity' is to be found in Tarin's writings that unveils the depths of the poet's knowledge, wisdom and deep understanding of the [[cultural heritage]] of his own society as well as [[Western culture|Western]] and other world literary-symbolic traditions.<ref>See Dr Tariq Rahman, Review of Omer Tarin's poetry in the Section 'Pakistani Literature in English' in 'The News' international, Islamabad ed, Pakistan, 6 December 1996</ref> One of Tarin's early poetic mentors, to whom he owes a great deal and to whom he himself paid tribute, was the late [[:simple:Taufiq Rafat|Taufiq Rafat]], one of the pioneers of English poetry in Pakistan/South Asia,<ref>[http://www.vallummag.com/essay_blaine_marchand.html A Review of Pakistani poetry with special reference to Rafat] Retrieved 4 December 2015</ref> an important scholar of [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]] Sufic poetry in his own right.<ref>Tarin, "Taufiq Rafat: In Memoriam", obituary in ''The Pulse'' weekly, Islamabad, 30 Sept-6 Oct 1998, n.p</ref> His indelible influence is quite manifest in Tarin's own poetical development.<ref>Rahman, Dec 2006, aa</ref>
Tarin's poetry reflects certain basic, recurring qualities such as a broad, universal humanity; a [[mystical]] regard for nature, life and the universe;<ref>[http://www.alibris.com/community/review/10965784/Tarin-Weaves-Magic-Spell/ Dr Iftikhar Malik Review]</ref><ref>[https://www.facebook.com/notes/pakistani-english-literature/omer-tarins-poetry-a-critical-evaluation-of-poetic-imagery-in-a-sad-piper-/600428426747237/ S J Renfrew, Critical review 2003 in Modern Poetry] Retrieved 14 November 2017</ref> a sense of the frailty of human existence and a continued concern with the central issues of life/death and immortality;<ref>{{cite web|author=E. Cyprian|title=Critical review|publisher="The Nation"|date=16 July 1995|url=http://www.nation.com.pk|accessdate=19 November 2012}}</ref> which also inform his style, and the system of [[Symbolism (arts)|symbolism]] and images that consequently arises from this, via which "...new patterns emerge in our perception of the world, of creation, of ourselves and our motivations".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/harvest-season-love-songs-Poems/product-reviews/9698127119 |title=Customer Reviews: The harvest season of love songs: Poems |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=19 November 2012}}</ref>
==Books== Tarin's major publications include:<ref>For further details see [https://openlibrary.org/authors/OL101176A/Omar_Tarin The Open Library Catalog for Omer Tarin]</ref> * ''A Sad Piper: Poems'' (1994 first edition) {{ISBN|969-8127-03-8}} * ''The Anvil of Dreams: Poems'' (1995) {{ISBN|969-8127-04-6}} * ''Burnt Offerings'', Poems (1996) {{ISBN|969-8127-07-0}} * ''The Harvest Season of Love Songs: Poems'' (1997) {{ISBN|969-8127-11-9}} * ''Riverbeds Flowing: Poems'' (1999; reprint 2009) * ''Sepoys and Sowars: Historical Essays'' (2000) {{ISBN|969-814-01-07}} * ''Selected Shorter Essays'' (2011) {{ISBN|978-1-105-15532-1}} * ''From Hill and Plain: Selected Short Stories'' (2011) {{ISBN|978-1-105-18623-3}}
==See also== * [[Pakistani poetry]] * [[List of Pakistani writers]] * [[List of Pakistani poets]] * [[Sufism]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== * A. Rahim, Ed. (1999) "A Select Bibliography of Pakistani Literature in English" ed A Rahim, Islamabad. * Ian Hamilton, Ed. (1994). Section on Pakistani English poets/writers in "The Oxford Companion to 20th Century Literature". *"Poetry International" (Asia section), Ed by Edwin Thumboo, Vol 7/8, SDSU Press, CA, USA, 2003. [http://www.sdsupress.sdsu.edu/2003/poetry/international] *Review of Pakistani Literature in English in the "Journal of [[Commonwealth]] Literature ", 1997 *Alamgir Hashmi, "Pakistani Literatura in 1993 and 1994" pub in Revista Alicantina de Studios Ingleses, No. 13 (2000) *Tariq Rahman "Review of Pakistani English Poetry", The News on Friday, The News International, Islamabad ed, 6 December 1996. *Tariq Rahman "A History of Pakistani Literature in English", Lahore: Vanguard Books, 1991. *O. Tarin "Taufiq Rafat: In Memoriam", in ''Pulse'' Weekly, Islamabad, 30–6 Sep Oct 1998, np. *Luminita Karim, Weekly Poetry Review, Daily ''The [[Muslim]]'', Islamabad, 28 Oct 1994 *B. King ed (1996) "New National and Postcolonial Literatures" [[Oxford]]: [[Clarendon Press]]. *Eric Cyprian, "Poems of Considerable Merit"; A Critical Review of Omer Tarin's "The Anvil of Dreams" in daily ''The Nation'', Islamabad, 16 July 1995, np. *Ayesha K. Sadozai, Vermont, USA, 2013 [https://www.facebook.com/notes/659463687447617/ A Critical Note of the poem 'Safar Namah' by Omer Tarin] *Bina Shah [https://www.dawn.com/news/1240869 'Art Identity' article in the Dawn , Karachi, 21 February 2016] Retrieved 27th Sept 2017
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Tarin, Omer}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1967 births]] [[Category:Pakistani writers]] [[Category:Pakistani poets]] [[Category:English-language poets from Pakistan]] [[Category:Pakistani academics]] [[Category:Pakistani scholars]] [[Category:Hindkowan people]] [[Category:People from Haripur District]] [[Category:Punjabi people]] [[Category:Aitchison College alumni]] [[Category:Pakistani Sufis]] [[Category:Sufi poets]] [[Category:Chishti Order]] [[Category:Chishtis]] [[Category:Rinzai Buddhists]] [[Category:Pakistani nature writers]] [[Category:University of the Punjab alumni]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Asiatic Society]]

revision.text:
{{Italic title}} {{taxobox |image = Parthenium argentatum (USDA).jpg |regnum = [[Plant]]ae |unranked_divisio = [[Flowering plant|Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]] |ordo = [[Asterales]] |familia = [[Asteraceae]] |tribus = Heliantheae |tribus_authority = Cass., 1819 |genus = ''[[Parthenium]]'' |species = '''''P. argentatum''''' |binomial = ''Parthenium argentatum'' |binomial_authority = [[A.Gray]] |}}
'''''Parthenium argentatum''''', commonly known as the '''guayule''' ({{IPAc-en|ɡ|w|aɪ|ˈ|uː|l|iː}} or {{IPAc-en|w|aɪ|ˈ|uː|l|eɪ}},<ref>{{OED|guayule}}</ref> as in [[Spanish language|Spanish]]), is a [[Flowering plant|flowering]] [[shrub]] in the [[Aster (genus)|aster]] family, [[Asteraceae]], that is native to the [[southwestern United States]] and northern [[Mexico]]. It was originally discovered by [[John Milton Bigelow |J.M. Bigelow]] in 1852 and was first described by [[Asa Gray]].<ref>Lloyd, F. E. (1911). [https://books.google.com/books?id=iA4bAAAAYAAJ&dq=parthenium%20argentatum%20gray&pg=PP2#v=onepage&q=parthenium%20argentatum%20gray&f=false Guayule (parthenium argentatum gray), a rubber-plant of the chihuahuan desert. Washington, D.C.: Carnegie Institution of Washington.]</ref> It can be found in the US states of [[New Mexico]] and [[Texas]] and the Mexican states of [[Zacatecas]], [[Coahuila]], [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], [[San Luis Potosí]], [[Nuevo León]], and [[Tamaulipas]].<ref>[http://www.hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/proceedings1996/V3-336.html Identification of Guayule Regions in Northern Mexico, Based on Rubber Yield and Coproducts Quality<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=PARTH2 PLANTS Profile for Parthenium (feverfew) | USDA PLANTS<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The plant can be used as an alternative source of [[latex]] that is also [[hypoallergenic]], unlike the normal ''[[Hevea brasiliensis|Hevea]]'' rubber. In [[pre-Columbian]] times, the guayule was a secondary source of latex for [[Natural rubber|rubber]], the principal source being the ''[[Castilla elastica]]'' tree. The name "guayule" derives from the [[Nahuatl]] word ''ulli/olli'', "rubber".
==Range and habitat== For sustainable production, guayule grows well in [[arid]] and semi arid areas of the southwestern United States, North Central Mexico and regions with similar climates around the world. Because the guayule plant produces [[terpene]] [[resin]]s, which are natural [[pesticide]]s, it is resistant to many pests and diseases. [[Herbicide]]s are primarily necessary for stand establishment.
==Commercial rubber latex source== In the 1920s, the plant saw a brief and intense amount of agricultural research when the Intercontinental Rubber Company in [[California]] produced 1400 tons of rubber after leaf blight decimated the Brazilian rubber industry. Guayule would again become a replacement for ''Hevea'' tree-produced latex during [[World War II]] when [[Empire of Japan|Japan]] cut off America's [[Malaysia]]n [[latex]] resources. The war ended before large-scale farming of the guayule plant began, and the project was scrapped, as it was cheaper to import tree-derived latex than to crush the shrubs for a smaller amount of latex.
Currently, PanAridus and Yulex are the only commercial producers of guayule natural rubber in the world. Yulex have partnered with Patagonia who are now making its Yulex wetsuit from Guayule derived plant stems in a 60/40 blend (60% guayule, 40% [[neoprene]]), reducing dependence on conventional neoprene.
In October 2015, the [[Bridgestone|Bridgestone Corporation]] announced the creation of the first tires made entirely of guayule rubber, having built an experimental farm and biorubber research center in [[Mesa, Arizona]] the previous year. The guayule is grown in Mesa and Eloy, Arizona.<ref>Bridgestone. [http://www.bridgestoneamericas.com/en/newsroom/press-releases/2015/-from-seed-to-tread--bridgestone-reveals-first-tires-made-entire From Seed to Tread: Bridgestone Reveals First Tires Made Entirely of Natural Rubber Components from Company’s Guayule Research Operations]. October 1, 2015.</ref><ref>Godfrey, Trevor. [http://www.eastvalleytribune.com/local/mesa/article_004332f8-4061-11e4-b2fd-4b73a8c5c3cb.html Bridgestone opens research center in Mesa]. East Valley Tribune. September 21, 2014.</ref>
==Hypoallergenic properties== {{unreferenced section|date=September 2013}} [[Image:GuayuleProducts.jpg|left|thumb|Experimental products made from guayule.]] Recently, the guayule plant has seen a small but growing resurgence in research and agriculture<ref>https://hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/proceedings1993/V2-338.html</ref> due to its [[hypoallergenic]] properties. While ''[[Hevea]]''-derived rubber contains [[protein]]s that can cause severe allergic reactions in a few people, guayule does not. With the [[AIDS]] crisis of the 1980s, the surge in rubber glove usage revealed how many people were [[Latex allergy|allergic to latex]] (about 10% of health care workers, according to [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration|OSHA]]), and thereby created a niche market for guayule. There are [[Synthetic rubber|synthetic alternatives]] for medical device products, but they are not as stretchable as natural rubber. Guayule performs like ''Hevea'' but contains none of the proteins that cause latex allergies.
==Breeding and production== Selection of high-yielding guayule is complicated by its breeding system, which is primarily [[apomixis]] (asexual cloning via gametes). However, the breeding system is somewhat variable and considerable genetic variation exists within wild populations. Selection of high-yielding lines has been successful.<ref>{{cite journal| last=Ray | first=Dennis T. |author2=Terry A. Coffelt |author3=David A. Dierig | year=2004 | title=Breeding Guayule for commercial production | journal=Industrial Crops and Products | volume=22 | issue=1 | pages=15–25 | doi=10.1016/j.indcrop.2004.06.005| url=https://naldc.nal.usda.gov/naldc/download.xhtml?id=4314&content=PDF }}</ref>
==Biofuel== Guayule's viability as a potential [[biofuel]] has been enhanced recently in light of commentary from a variety of experts, including [[Lester R. Brown]] of the [[Earth Policy Institute]], stating that "[food based] biofuels pit the 800 million people with cars against the 800 million people with hunger problems,"<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1725975-3,00.html |title=The Clean Energy Scam |first=Michael |last=Grunwald |date=2008-03-27 |journal=TIME}}</ref> meaning that biofuels derived from food crops (like [[maize]]) raise world food prices. Guayule can be an economically viable biofuel crop that does not increase the world's hunger problem.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://guayuleblog.com/29/alternative-energy/world-needs-alternatives-to-biofuels-from-food-crops/ |first=Julie |last=Wright |title=World needs alternatives to biofuels from food crops |publisher=Guayule Blog |date=2008-04-03 |accessdate=2009-09-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090914033116/http://guayuleblog.com/29/alternative-energy/world-needs-alternatives-to-biofuels-from-food-crops/ |archivedate=2009-09-14 |df= }}</ref> Guayule has another benefit over food crops as biofuel - it can be grown in areas where food crops would fail.
==See also== * ''[[Taraxacum kok-saghyz]]''; the rubber dandelion, produces similar hypoallergenic rubber, even in cold climates
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{commonscat-inline|Parthenium argentatum|''Parthenium argentatum''}} {{Wikispecies-inline}} *[http://www.hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/proceedings1993/v2-338.html Guayule: A Source of Natural Rubber] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080430111314/http://guayuleblog.com/ GuayuleBlog.com]
{{Taxonbar|from=Q536839}}

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox Organization |name = Pneurop |image = |size = |caption = |abbreviation = |motto = |formation = 1960 |extinction = |type = Trade association |status = Non-profit company |purpose = Compressed air products and vacuum pumps in Europe |headquarters = 80 Bd Reyers, 1030 Brussels, Belgium |region_served = Europe |membership = European compressed air companies |language = |leader_title = President |leader_name = Dr Paul Frigne |main_organ = |parent_organization = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.pneurop.eu Pneurop] |remarks = General Secretary is Stéphanie UNY }}
'''PNEUROP''' is the European Association of manufacturers of compressors, vacuum pumps, pneumatic tools and allied equipment, represented by their national associations.
==History== The compressed air trade associations of France, Germany and the UK formed a trading organization in 1958.In 1960, more countries joined and it became PNEUROP.
PNEUROP celebrated its formal 50th anniversary on 6 November 2008 by organizing a conference in Brussels with its programme and presentations by the different committees.<ref>[http://www.pneurop.eu/index.php?pagename=Pneurop_50th_Anniversary_Conference_in_Brussels 50th Anniversary Event]</ref>
==Function== PNEUROP speaks on behalf of its members in European and international forums concerning the harmonisation of technical, normative<ref>{{cite web|title=Becker pumps|url=http://www.beckerpumps.com|accessdate=28 November 2016}}</ref><ref>[http://www.pneurop.eu/index.php?pagename=Pneurop_Publications Pneurop list of publications]</ref> and legislative developments in the field of compressors, vacuum pumps, pneumatic tools and allied equipment.
The association is cooperating with and contributing to several ISO committees including TC 112 (Vacuum Technology) and TC 118 (Compressor).
PNEUROP is committed to develop energy efficiency and environmental protection among its member organizations and members, as explained in a recent official statement.<ref>[http://www.pneurop.eu/uploads/documents/pdf/Pneurop_Commitment_to_Energy_Efficiency_and_Environmental_Protection.pdf Commitment for Industry Sustainability]</ref> Pneurop supports the overall sustainable energy policy objectives of the European Union and its member companies actively promote energy efficiency as part of their daily business activity.{{cn|date=November 2016}}
Pneurop is registered under the European Union 'Transparency Register' - ID number: [http://ec.europa.eu/transparencyregister/public/consultation/displaylobbyist.do?id=67236492080-88 67236492080-88 ]
== "Air Everywhere" == {{unreferenced|section|date=November 2012}} The PNEUROP General Assembly officially approved the launch of a new project entitled “Pneurop Green Challenge 2020". Through this project, manufacturers, represented by their national associations, wish to draw attention to the importance of their equipment which is vital in reaching Europe’s 2020 goals in terms of energy savings, development of renewable energy and a reduction in CO2 emissions. Compressors and vacuum pumps are used not only in projects for storage of CO<sub>2</sub> but also in the manufacture of photovoltaic cells and in the transport and storage of hydrogen. These examples are part of the vast list of products and applications which professionals would like to make better known to the general public.
This determination to develop and promote these technologies of the future is the consequence of the industry’s long-held commitment to reduce the environmental impact of the different production phases, to develop an ecologically sound approach to product design, and to encourage recycling of products.
Sustainability projects and low carbon initiatives need compressed air, gas and vacuum equipment. This is formalized under a signature and a logo "Air Everywhere".
== Ecodesign == Pneurop is an active stakeholder of the Ecodesign Preparatory Study on Electric motor systems/compressors (Ener Lot 31)<ref>{{cite web|last=VHK|first=consultancy|title=Lot 31 ecodesign|url=http://www.eco-compressors.eu/index.html}}</ref>
==Structure== PNEUROP's office is located in Diamant Building in [[Brussels]]. The work is achieved through product network : * Compressors * Tools * Vacuum technology * Pressure equipment * Air treatment * Process compressors
PNEUROP is an international brand/trade name that was registered in 2007 with its logo.<ref>[http://www.pneurop.eu/images/pneurop_logo_larger.gif Pneurop Logo]</ref>
===Member organizations=== * {{flagicon|Europe}} [[Orgalime]] * {{flagicon|Austria}} [[FMMI]] * {{flagicon|Belgium}} [[AGORIA]] * {{flagicon|Finland}} Technology Industries of Finland * {{flagicon|France}} [[Profluid]]<ref>[http://www.profluid.org Profluid website]</ref> * {{flagicon|Germany}} [[VDMA]] - Compressors, Compressed Air and Vacuum Technology * {{flagicon|Italy}} [[ANIMA]] * {{flagicon|Sweden}} [[Teknikforetagen]] * {{flagicon|Switzerland}} [[Swissmem]] * {{flagicon|Turkey}} Association of Machine Manufacturers [[MÝB]]<ref>[http://www.mib.org MIB website]</ref> * {{flagicon|UK}} British Compressed Air Society Limited - [[British Compressed Air Society|BCAS]] * ISO International Organisation for Standardisation [[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]]<ref>[http://www.iso.org ISO website]</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.pneurop.eu/index.php Pneurop website]

{{about|the physical process|the ecological technique|Rarefaction (ecology)}} {{Refimprove|date=October 2012}} [[Image:Onde compression impulsion 1d 30 petit.gif|thumb|305px| An example of rarefaction is also as a [[Phase (waves)|phase]] in a [[sound]] wave or [[phonon]]. Half of a [[sound wave]] is made up of the compression of the [[Transmission medium|medium]], and the other half is the decompression or ''rarefaction'' of the medium.]] '''Rarefaction''' is the reduction of an item's density, the opposite of [[compression (physical)|compression]].<ref name="Encyclopædia Britannica">{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/491599/rarefaction|title=rarefaction}}</ref> Like compression, which can travel in waves ([[sound wave]]s, for instance), rarefaction waves also exist in nature. A common rarefaction wave is the area of low relative pressure following a [[shock wave]] (see picture).
Rarefaction waves expand with time (much like sea waves spread out as they reach a beach); in most cases rarefaction waves keep the same overall profile ('shape') at all times throughout the wave's movement: it is a ''self-similar expansion''. Each part of the wave travels at the local speed of sound, in the local medium. This expansion behaviour is in contrast to the behaviour of pressure increases, which gets narrower with time, until they steepen into [[shock wave]]s.
==Physical examples==
A natural example of rarefaction occurs in the layers of [[Earth's atmosphere]]. Because the atmosphere has [[mass]], most atmospheric [[matter]] is nearer to the Earth due to the Earth's [[gravitation]]. Therefore, air at higher layers of the atmosphere is less dense, or ''rarefied'', relative to air at lower layers. Thus rarefaction can refer either to a reduction in density over space at a single point of time, or a reduction of density over time for one particular area.
Rarefaction can be easily observed by compressing a [[Spring (device)|spring]] and releasing it. Instead of seeing compressed loops seeming to move through the spring, spaced-out loops move through it: rarefaction waves.
==Rarefaction in manufacturing==
Modern construction of guitars is an example of using rarefaction in manufacturing. By forcing the reduction of density (loss of oils and other impurities) in the cellular structure of the soundboard, a rarefied guitar top produces a tonal decompression affecting the sound of the instrument, mimicking aged wood.
== See also == * [[Longitudinal wave]] * [[P-wave]] * [[Prandtl–Meyer expansion fan]]

revision.text:
{{redirect|Krasny Les|the villages in the Czech Republic|Krásný Les (disambiguation)}} {{unreferenced|date=December 2016}} [[File:Romintosgiria2.JPG|thumb|300px|Romincka Forest]] '''Romincka Forest''' ({{lang-pl|Puszcza Romincka}}, {{lang-lt|Romintos giria}}), also known as '''Krasny Les''' ({{lang-ru|Красный лес}}) or '''Rominte Heath''' ({{lang-de|Rominter Heide}}), is an extended forest and heath landscape stretching from the southeast of Russian [[Kaliningrad Oblast]] to the northeast of Polish [[Warmian-Masurian Voivodeship]]. The [[palaearctic]] [[ecoregion]] is part of the [[Taiga|Taiga and boreal forests]] [[biome]].
==Etymology== The Polish and German names of the forest, like the ''[[Krasnaya River|Rominta/Rominte]]'' river and the settlement of ''[[Krasnolesye|Rominty/Rominten]]'', are derived from the [[Lithuanian language|Lithuanian]] syllable ''rom'', meaning calm, as the forest is in the land called [[Lithuania Minor]]. The Russian name, ''Krasny Les'', means "Red Forest".
==Geography== [[File:Suwalszczyzna.png|thumb|left|Map of [[Suwalszczyzna]] with Romincka Forest in the northwest]] The total area of the Romincka landscape is about {{convert|250|km2}}, stretching from the [[Masurian Lake District]] in the southwest up to the border with [[Lithuania]] at [[Lake Vištytis]] in the east. The southern Polish part (about one-third of the area) comprises a protected zone known as [[Puszcza Romincka Landscape Park]].
The [[Krasnaya River]] flows through the Romincka Forest. Major settlements in the area include [[Krasnolesye]] in Kaliningrad Oblast, as well as [[Żytkiejmy]] and [[Gołdap]] in Poland.
==History== [[File:JagdschlossRominten.jpg|thumb|Rominten hunting lodge, 1914 postcard]] Part of the [[East Prussia]]n historic region, the extended forests were known for its [[red deer]] populations and became a popular hunting ground of the [[House of Hohenzollern|Hohenzollern]] princes ruling the [[Duchy of Prussia]] since 1525. Part of the [[German Empire]] from 1871 onwards, a vast premise in ''Rominter Heide'' was purchased by Emperor [[Wilhelm II, German Emperor|Wilhelm II]], who had his [[Rominten Hunting Lodge]] erected here in 1891, including a chapel dedicated to Saint [[Hubertus]]. Hunt scenes were perpetuated by notable painters such as [[Richard Friese]] (1854–1918).
Plundered by Russian forces in World War I, the hunting lodge and grounds upon Wilhelm's resignation in 1918 were administrated by the [[Free State of Prussia]]; Minister-President [[Otto Braun]] was a regular guest. Later on, the estates were seized by [[Nazi Germany|Nazi]] minister [[Hermann Göring]], whose ''[[Reichsjägerhof Rominten]]'' was built nearby in 1936. It also served as Göring's headquarters during the German [[Operation Barbarossa]] in 1941.
The Allied [[Potsdam Agreement]] after World War II divided the region between the re-established [[Polish People's Republic|Polish Republic]] and the [[Soviet Union]]. The German history of the region is documented at the [[East Prussian Regional Museum]] in [[Lüneburg]] and at the [[Deutsches Jagd- und Fischereimuseum|German Hunting and Fishing Museum]] in [[Munich]]. In recent years, hunting tourism has again become popular.
==See also== *[[:Category:Taiga and boreal forests|Index: Taiga and boreal forests Ecoregion]]

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=April 2010}} {{primary sources|date=April 2010}} }}
{{-}} {{Infobox ecoregion | name = Sierra Madre de Oaxaca pine-oak forests | image = Oaxaqa (41).jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = Cerro San Felipe, located in the Parque Nacional Benito Juarez is the only federally protected area of the Sierra Madre de Oaxaca, and is important as the watersource for the city of [[Oaxaca]] <!-- *** Country etc. *** --> | country = Mexico | border = [[Tehuacan Valley matorral]] | border1 = [[Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt pine-oak forests]] | border2 = [[Oaxacan montane forests]] | border3 = [[Peten-Veracruz moist forests]] | border4 = [[Southern Pacific dry forests]] | border5 = [[Sierra Madre del Sur pine-oak forests]] | border6 = [[Balsas dry forests]] <!-- *** Free fields *** --> | bird_species = 447<ref name = "Atlas"> {{cite book |last1 = Hoekstra |first1 = J. M. |last2 = Molnar |first2 = J. L. |last3 = Jennings |first3 = M. |last4 = Revenga |first4 = C. |last5 = Spalding |first5 = M. D. |last6 = Boucher |first6 = T. M. |last7 = Robertson |first7 = J. C. |last8 = Heibel |first8 = T. J. |last9 = Ellison |first9 = K. |title = The Atlas of Global Conservation: Changes, Challenges, and Opportunities to Make a Difference |publisher = [[University of California Press]] |editor1-last = Molnar |editor1-first = J. L. |year = 2010 |isbn = 978-0-520-26256-0 |url=http://www.nature.org/multimedia/maps/ }}</ref> | mammal_species = 176<ref name = "Atlas"/> | habitat_loss = 15.078 | habitat_loss_ref = <ref name = "Atlas"/> | protected = 5.25 | protected_ref = <ref name = "Atlas"/> | area = 14300 | biome = [[Tropical and subtropical coniferous forests]] | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = }} [[File:Sierra Madre de Oaxaca Pine-Oak Forests map.svg|thumb|300px|'''Sierra Madre de Oaxaca Pine-Oak Forests''' ecoregion, southern Mexico.]] The '''Sierra Madre de Oaxaca pine-oak forests''' is an [[ecoregion]] of the [[Tropical and subtropical coniferous forests]] [[biome]], in Southern [[Mexico]].
It occupies the [[Sierra Madre de Oaxaca]], a mountain range which lies mostly within the state of [[Oaxaca]], and extends north into [[Puebla]] and [[Veracruz]] states. It is one of a chain of pine-oak forest ecoregions extending along the [[American Cordillera]] from [[Oregon]] and [[California]] in the north to [[Nicaragua]] in the south. [[File:Bosque Cajonos.JPG|left|thumb|Pine Forest between San Isidro Llano Grande and San Miguel Cajonos, in the [[Sierra Madre de Oaxaca]].]]
==Geography== The ecoregion covers an area of {{convert|14,300|km2|sqmi|sp=us}}, lying above {{convert|1600|m|ft}} elevation. The [[Sierra Madre de Oaxaca]] runs northeast-southwest, extending {{convert|300|km|mi}} from [[Pico de Orizaba]] in the northeast to extends to the [[Isthmus of Tehuantepec]] in the southeast. Peaks in the Sierra Madre de Oaxaca average {{convert|2500|m|ft}} meters in elevation, with some peaks exceeding {{convert|3000|m|ft}}. The range intercepts humid air moving west from the [[Gulf of Mexico]].
===Adjacent ecoregions=== The [[Gulf Coastal Plain]] lies to the east, and a series of river valleys separate the Sierra Madre de Oaxaca from the [[Sierra Madre del Sur]] to the southwest and the [[Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt]] to the northwest. The ecoregion is bounded on the east by the humid [[Oaxacan montane forests]], which lie below {{convert|1600|m|ft}} elevation. To the east, the [[deserts and xeric shrublands|xeric]] [[Tehuacan Valley matorral]] occupies the Tehuacan valley to the northwest, the [[Jalisco dry forests]] occupy the upper basin of the [[Santo Domingo River]], which lies in the rain shadow of the Sierra, and the [[Southern Pacific dry forests]] lie to the south along the Pacific coast, extending into the upper basin of the [[Tehuantepec River]] and the [[Valley of Oaxaca]]. The dry forests separate the Sierra Madre de Oaxaca pine-oak forests from the [[Sierra Madre del Sur pine-oak forests]] to the southwest.
==Flora== The associated vegetation of the pine-oak forests varies with elevation and exposure. Besides the [[Pinus|pines]] (''Pinus'' spp.) and [[Quercus|oaks]] (''Quercus'' spp.) trees, the forests can have a great diversity of [[bromeliads]], [[orchids]], [[fern]]s. [[File:Bosque Comaltepec.JPG|right|thumb|upright|The communal land of the Chinantec Community of Santiago Comaltepec contains cloud forest.]]
==Fauna== The forests of the Sierra Madre de Oaxaca are one of the last remaining habitats with [[Jaguar]] and [[Puma (genus)|Puma]] in Mexico.
==People== The Pine-Oak forests of the Sierra Madre de Oaxaca have been inhabited for a millennia by indigenous cultures. The primary cultures are of the [[Mazatec people|Mazatec]], [[Zapotec peoples|Zapotec]], [[Mixe]], [[Cuicatec]], and [[Chinantec]] peoples. [[File:Rhynchostele cervantesii ssp. membranacea.JPG|left|thumb|Rhynchostele cervantesii ssp. membranacea is one of the many [[orchids]] that inhabit the high forests of the Sierra Madre de Oaxaca.]]
==Conservation and threats== Some of the Sierra Madre de Oaxaca pine-oak forest [[habitat]]s/areas are among the better conserved forests in Mexico. However, only a small fraction its virgin/[[old growth forest]]s are protected by the Federal government, within [[Benito Juárez National Park]] (''Parque Nacional Benito Juarez'') located north of Oaxaca city.
Most conservation in the Sierra Madre de Oaxaca is controlled by indigenous communities. For example, Santiago Comaltepec's vast expanse of [[cloud forest]]s is considered some of the best conserved cloud forests in the world. Many communities, notably Ixtlán de Juárez and the Pueblo Mancomunados, among others, strive to conserve their forest through projects including sustainable forestry and selective logging, ecotourism, education projects, and the prohibition of private property within their communities (thus hampering unsustainable development and industry by foreign or outside agents).
The forests are under threat by foreign investment, and by mining and logging commissions to foreign companies from the Oaxaca state government.
==See also== *{{C|Sierra Madre de Oaxaca|Sierra Madre de Oaxaca topics}} *[[Conifers of Mexico]] *[[List of ecoregions in Mexico]] *{{C|Trees of Southern Mexico}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{WWF ecoregion|name=Sierra Madre de Oaxaca pine-oak forests|id=nt0308}}
